question_sets.context:
The big red American car was much too wide for an English country road. When Jack saw it coming toward him, he stopped his own car at the side of the road to make room for it to pass. The American car went slowly so close that he could see the driver"s face quite clearly.
"Where have I seen that face before? "he thought, "Wait a minute! I remember now. It was in the newspaper! "He took out the newspaper from his bag, turned quickly to the middle page. There was a picture of the face in it. Yes, it had a large mouth and small ears, and his eyes were behind dark glasses. "Wanted by the police, "read by Jack. "The City Bank will give a lot of money to anyone who helps the police to catch this man. "
"Call the police at once, "he said to himself. But a few minutes later, he was sad. "This man was caught this morning. "answered the police.

questions.text: In which country did the story happen?
questions.explanation: The story happened in England.

choices.A: He didn't want to pass by first.
choices.B: He wanted to see who the driver was.
choices.C: Because it was good for an Englishman to stop to let others go.
choices.D: The road was not wide enough for the two cars to pass at the same time.

questions.explanation: The road was not wide enough for the two cars to pass at the same time.

questions.text: Who was wanted by the police in the passage?

choices.D: The driver in the American car.

questions.explanation: The driver in the American car was wanted by the police.

question_sets.context:
Reading is like riding a bicycle. You don't read everything at the same speed. How fast you read often depends upon your reason for reading. Sometimes you need to read slowly and carefully. You do this when you study. You also read slowly when you are following a set of directions (说明).
Sometimes you don't want to read a whole article or story. You may just be looking for a fact you need to know. Or you might be looking for the answer to a question. When you read very quickly for such a purpose (目的), you are skimming (略读). The article you are reading may have subheadings (副标题)or less important titles. You can use these to help you find the part of the article you want.
Other times you may be reading for fun. You read most novels (小说)this way. You don't have to remember facts or ideas, so you read rather quickly. You often need to read such stories only once.

questions.text: When you read stories for fun, you generally read them <blank>.
questions.explanation: When reading stories for fun, you read them no more than once.

questions.text: You can skim when you <blank>.

choices.B: are following a set of directions
choices.C: ignore (忽略)the subheadings of an article
choices.D: don't want to know all the details (细节)of a whole article or story

questions.explanation: When you don't want to know all the details of a whole article or story, you can skim.

questions.text: When you read a novel for fun, you <blank>.

choices.A: skim because the details are not important any way
choices.B: read it quickly so that you only have to read it once
choices.C: read carefully because many things in the novel are not true
choices.D: read quickly because it is not necessary to remember the details

questions.explanation: When you read a novel for fun, you read quickly because it is not necessary to remember the details.

questions.text: This article compares (比喻)reading to riding a bicycle because <blank>.

choices.A: you should read as fast as you ride a bicycle
choices.B: reading is as much a pleasure as riding a bicycle
choices.C: you change speeds in reading as well as in riding a bicycle
choices.D: you must read slowly as you ride a bicycle slowly for safety

questions.explanation: This article compares reading to riding a bicycle because you change speeds in reading as well as in riding a bicycle.

question_sets.context:
The village was a long way from the town. It was twelve or thirteen hundred kilometers.
"You must go to the city,"I said to Atalipa."Only a doctor can help you. I am not a doctor,you know. But I'll go with you."
"Go along the river,"he said,"Then climb over the great mountains."
"Yes. That's the only way."
"That's quite a long way and my people have never gone to places so far!"
Atalipa did not enjoy the city very much. But we stayed for two months ,and he got better. Then we went back to the great mountains,and went down the river in Atalipa's little wooden boat.Atalipa rowed for days before they got back to the village.
I asked him,"What are you going to tell your people? Will you talk about the city men? What will you talk about the high buildings and the cars?"
He thought for a minute. The he said,"No, I won't tell them. They won't understand;and maybe they'll cry."
"What do you mean? Why will they cry?"
"All men love their homes,"he answered."My people are happy in their village. It's their home."
"Yes,of course. But why will they cry?"I asked.
"Because the city is your home. You're staying with us.So they'll cry for you."

questions.text: Why did Atalipa go to the city?

choices.A: Because he wanted to see the city .
choices.B: Because he wanted to go farther than his people.
choices.C: Because he had to go to see a doctor.
choices.D: Because he wanted to see the buildings and cars.

questions.explanation: Atalipa went to the city because he needed to see a doctor.

questions.text: Why did Atalipa think his people would cry for the writer of the passage?

choices.A: His people didn't think it was happy for the writer to be away from his home.
choices.B: His people did not want the writer to leave .
choices.C: The writer's home was so good but his people's were so poor.
choices.D: Living in the city was much better,so his people would all leave.

questions.explanation: Atalipa's people thought the writer would be sad to be away from their home in the city.

questions.text: How could the people in that village go to the city?

choices.B: They could only go by boat.
choices.C: They could go by boat,and then they had to go on foot.
choices.D: They could never go out so far to any other city.

questions.explanation: The people had to go by boat along the river and then climb over the mountains on foot.

questions.explanation: The writer says that the city is his home.

choices.A: He was not happy at home in the city,so he went to that village
choices.B: He must be a traveller there.
choices.C: He was a writer and he was writing about poor life in the village.
choices.D: He must be a person who sent to work to help the people there.

questions.explanation: The writer seemed to be working to help the people there.

question_sets.context:
Families in Canada have changed in the last 40 years.In the 1950s,most families had two parents.The father went to work and the mother stayed at home with two or more children.How are the families different in the 1990s?
Families are smaller
The average family has 3.1 people.
Single-parent families
One out of five children lives in a single-parent family. Most single parents are women.
Common-law families
One out of ten children is raised by parents who are not legally married to each other.
Working mothers
More mothers work outside the home. Sixty-four percent of married women with children under16 work outside the home.
Divorce and marriage
Forty-one percent of all marriages end in divorce. Thirty percent of all marriages are remarriages.

questions.explanation: The passage discusses how families in Canada have changed.

choices.A: the families in the 1990s have fewer people than those in the 1950s
choices.C: 64%of women are married when they are under 16
choices.D: one-fifth of the children are raised by their fathers when their parents get divorced

questions.explanation: The passage states that families are smaller now.

choices.A: go out to work in order to make a living
choices.B: raise their children when they get divorced
choices.C: stay at home to look after their children and do housework

questions.explanation: The passage states more mothers work outside the home, so go out to work in order to make a living

questions.explanation: The capital of Canada is Ottawa

In English,many word ssound similar,and that is why misunderstanding
(误解) among English-speaking people are not uncommon.
Once a man got on a bus for New York.He hid in the toilet,because he did not want to pay.But a passenger saw him.She tapped(轻拍) the person in front of her on the shoulder and said,"There's a bum(流浪汉) in th toilet.Tell the bus driver."That passenger tapped the person in front of him."Tell the bus driver there's a bum in the toilet,"he said.
The message was passed from person to person.But somewhere along the way,it changed.The bus driver was told that there was a bomb(炸弹) in the toilet.He stopped the bus at once and telephoned the police.When the police arrived,they told the passengers to get off the bus and stay far away.Then they closed the highroad.That soon caused a 15-mile-long traffic jam (堵塞).With the help of a dog,the police searched for two hours.Of course,they found no bomb!

question_sets.context:
Hayao Miyazaki was born in Tokyo on January 5, 1941. As a boy, he liked to read and draw cartoons. After graduating from university in 1963, Miyazaki joined the Toei Animation (动画片制作) Company. At Toei, he worked on many animated movies, like the famousPuss in Boots. In 1984, he madeNausicaa of the Valley of Wind, which was based on a comic book he wrote. Because this movie was so successful, Miyazaki was able to start his own animation company, Studio Ghibli.
One of Miyazaki's most loved movies isMy Neighbour Totoro, made in 1987. It is a children's movie, but many teenagers and adults like it too. The movie is about two sisters who become friends with a big, supernatural (神奇的) animal named Totoro. It is a very warm-hearted story, with many strange and interesting characters such as Cat Bus, a cat which is also a bus. Miyazaki's 2001 movie,Spirited Away, was even more popular than My Neighbour Totoro.
All of Miyazaki's movies have strange but charming people and creatures. Many of his stories happen in worlds that are different from ours. However, they still show his ideas about real life. He often points out how humans hurt the natural world. He thinks people should change the ways how they live. This may be why so many people like his movies.

questions.text: What is the main idea of this passage?

choices.B: The early life of Hayao Miyazaki.
choices.C: The most famous movie in Japan.

questions.explanation: The passage discusses Miyazaki's life, career, and movies, making 'The works of Hayao Miyazaki' the most fitting main idea.

questions.text: How did the success ofNausicaa of the Valley of Windhelp Miyazaki?

choices.A: He was able to start his own company.
choices.B: He could sell a comic book.
choices.C: He could join Toei Animation Company.
choices.D: He could work on more movies.

questions.explanation: The passage states 'Because this movie was so successful, Miyazaki was able to start his own animation company, Studio Ghibli'.

questions.text: Which movie is "Cat Bus" in?
questions.explanation: The passage mentions 'My Neighbour Totoro' having 'many strange and interesting characters such as Cat Bus'.

questions.explanation: The passage states 'It is a children's movie, but many teenagers and adults like it too'.

questions.text: According to the passage, why are Miyazaki's movies so successful?

choices.B: His movies are all about real life.
choices.D: He wants to protect the environment.

questions.explanation: The last paragraph says 'He often points out how humans hurt the natural world. He thinks people should change the ways how they live. This may be why so many people like his movies.'

question_sets.context:
Tropical cyclones (热带旋风) are called typhoons (台风) in Asia, and hurricanes (飓风) in North and South America. These storms go around like a wheel(轮子) turning to the left. They have wind speeds of 60 kph or more. They can be very destructive (毁灭性的). In the United States, the Tropical Prediction Centre in Miami, Florida, looks out for hurricanes. When scientists discover a true hurricane, they give it a name. They can use either a man's or woman's name. Why should hurricanes have names? The names make it easier for people to keep up with information about a hurricane and its dangers.
The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), an international weather group, decides what names will be used. The WMO makes six lists (列表) of names, using the English alphabet. Each list is used for one year. When a hurricane happens, it gets the next name on the list for that year. For example, the first hurricane of the year might have the name Abel, while the second one could be Betty. The name lists do not include (包含) names beginning with the letters O, U, X, Y, and Z, since there are few names that begin with these letters. Asian countries use a different list. This list has a few personal names, but most of the names are of flowers, animals and trees.

questions.text: Why should hurricans have names?

choices.B: The names help people get information about a hurricane.
choices.C: The names are only for the WMO.

questions.explanation: The passage says, 'The names make it easier for people to keep up with information about a hurricane and its dangers'.

questions.text: <blank> decides what names will be used for hurricanes.
questions.explanation: The passage states 'The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), an international weather group, decides what names will be used'.

questions.text: Which name would a hurricane never have?
questions.explanation: The passage says names beginning with 'O, U, X, Y, and Z' are not used. 'Yanni' starts with 'Y'.

questions.text: The Fifth hurricane of 2010 might have the name <blank>.
questions.explanation: The first hurricane is Abel, the second is Betty, the third is Connie, and the fourth is Darren, so the fifth should be Diana.

questions.text: Asian countries name typhoons after <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage says 'This list has a few personal names, but most of the names are of flowers, animals and trees'.

question_sets.context:
One day Mrs Green took several pairs of shoes to a shoemaker to be repaired. After a few days she picked them up and put them away.
Six months later, she and her husband were asked to dinner. She took a pair of shoes. She hadn't worn them since they were repaired. She put one on her right foot, and then she put the other on her left. She felt something wrong. She took them off for a closer look. They were the same style color and size, but each was for the right foot. Then she thought of the shoemaker. Though she was sure he wouldn't remember her after such a long time, she called him.
"Thank goodness, you finally called" He said eacitedly(兴奋地). "An angry woman has been troubling me for months."

questions.text: The shoemaker finished repairing her shoes _________.
questions.explanation: The passage says 'After a few days she picked them up'.

questions.text: Mrs Green didn't know both shoes were for the right foot until ___ one day.
questions.explanation: The passage states that 'She hadn't worn them since they were repaired' and only discovered the problem when she tried to wear them.

questions.text: What did Mrs Green do after she found the wrong shoe?
questions.explanation: After realizing the mistake, 'Then she thought of the shoemaker...she called him'.

questions.text: The other woman was angry because _________.

choices.B: the shoemaker gave her two left shoes
choices.C: Mrs Green took away her shoes

questions.explanation: The shoemaker says, 'An angry woman has been troubling me for months', implying the woman received mismatched shoes.

questions.text: Which of the following is true?

choices.A: The shoemaker was angry with Mrs Green.
choices.B: The shoemaker said sorry to Mrs Green.
choices.C: The shoemaker was very glad When he received Mrs Green's call.
choices.D: The shoemaker didn't know someone had taken away the right shoe.

questions.explanation: The shoemaker's words, 'Thank goodness, you finally called', indicate he was relieved to hear from Mrs. Green.

question_sets.context:
Now cities are full of cars. Some families even have two or more cars. Parking is a great problem, and so is the traffic in and around the cities. Something will have to be done to change it. What will the cars of tomorrow be like?
Little cars may some day take the place of today's big cars. If everyone drives little cars in the future, there will be less pollution in the air. There will also be more space for parking cars in cities, and the streets will be less crowded. Three little cars can fit(适合) in the space now needed for one car of the usual size.
The little cars will cost much less to own to drive. Driving will be safer, too. What is more, these little cars can go about 65 kilometres per hour.
Little cars of the future will be fine for getting around a city, but they will not be useful for long trips. If big cars are still used along with the small ones, two sets of roads will be needed in the future. Some roads will be used for the big, fast cars, and other roads will be needed for the slower small ones.

questions.text: _________ is the big problem for those people who have cars.
questions.explanation: The passage states, 'Parking is a great problem'.

questions.text: Cars in the future will bring _________ pollution in the air.
questions.explanation: The passage mentions, 'If everyone drives little cars in the future, there will be less pollution in the air'.

questions.text: The little car's size may be _________ today's cars' size.
questions.explanation: The passage mentions, 'Three little cars can fit in the space now needed for one car of the usual size'.

questions.text: People can _________ money by using the little cars.
questions.explanation: The passage states, 'The little cars will cost much less to own to drive'.

questions.text: Little cars are very fine for _________.
questions.explanation: The passage says, 'Little cars of the future will be fine for getting around a city, but they will not be useful for long trips'.

question_sets.context:
Last week, we published(出版) an article(文章) about modern marriages. A recent survey(最近调查) showed that in England 51 percent of married women go out to work. People were asked what they thought of "working wives."
The results were as follows:

Men
Women
In favour(赞成)
70%
80%
Against
10%
20%
Don't know
20%
0%
We asked readers to write and tell us their opinions. Here are some of the hundreds of letters we received.
I'm a(woman) photographer. I make a lot of money, travel a lot, and meet a lot of people. I enjoy my work, and would hate to stay at home. I would never marry a man who wanted me to give up my work.
Ms Joip O'Leary
At present there are over 1,000,000 unemployed(未被雇用) men in Britain. If a woman gets a job, she puts one man out of work. Perhaps that man has a wife and twelve children to support. Let women stay at home where they belong.
Ted Stubbs
I am the mother of twelve children. When I go to work, my husband looks after the children. He is very good with the children and enjoy staying at home with them. And I enjoy my job as a bus driver.
Mrs. E. Boot

questions.text: _________ of the women are on the side of working wives.
questions.explanation: According to the survey results, 80% of women are in favor of working wives, which means 'Most' of the women are on that side.

choices.D: wants her to stay at home.

questions.explanation: Ms. Joip O'Leary says, 'I would never marry a man who wanted me to give up my work'.

choices.A: would make men lose chances for work.

questions.explanation: Ted Stubbs says, 'If a woman gets a job, she puts one man out of work'.

choices.A: her children take care of themselves.
choices.B: a nurse looks after her children.
choices.C: her husband looks after the children.
choices.D: she has to have everything ready for the children.

questions.explanation: Mrs. E. Boot says, 'When I go to work, my husband looks after the children'.

choices.B: men can stay at home to look after the children.

questions.explanation: Mrs. Boot's letter shows that men can look after children, women can enjoy their jobs, and roles can be exchanged.

question_sets.context:
In order to know a foreign language thoroughly, four things are necessary. Firstly, we must be able to understand the language when we hear it spoken. Secondly, we must be able to speak it ourselves, correctly, with confidence and without hesitation. Thirdly, we must be able to read the language and fourthly, we must be able to write it. We must be able to compose(组成)sentences that are grammatically correct. We must know how to arrange sentences in paragraphs, so as to write a good letter or composition.
There is no easy way to succeed in language learning. A good memory is of great help, but it is not enough simply to memorize rules from a grammar book. It is not much use learning by heart long lists of words and their meaning. We learn words not by ourselves, but in sentences. We must learn by using the language. "Learn through use" is a good piece of advice for those who are studying a new language. Practice is very important. We must practise speaking and writing the language whenever we can.

questions.text: The word "confidence" here probably means <blank>.
questions.explanation: Confidence means feeling sure of ourselves.

questions.text: The writer advises us to <blank>.
questions.explanation: The writer advises us to practise speaking and writing the language whenever we can.

questions.text: The first step in learning a language is <blank>.
questions.explanation: Firstly, we must be able to understand the language when we hear it spoken.

questions.text: Words should be learned <blank>.
questions.explanation: We learn words not by ourselves, but in sentences.

questions.text: "Learn through use "is to say that <blank>.

choices.A: we must practise speaking and writing
choices.B: we must learn by using the language
choices.C: we must learn everything by language
choices.D: we must remember grammar rules as many as possible

questions.explanation: We must learn by using the language.

question_sets.context:
We are all interested in equality, but while some people try to protect the school and examination system in the name of equality, others, still in the name of equality, want only to destroy it.
Any society which is interested in equality of opportunity(机会)and standards of achievement must regularly test its pupils. The standards may be changed - no examination is perfect - but to have no external( 外部的 )tests or examinations would mean the end of equality and of standards. There are groups of people who oppose this view and who do not believe either in external examinations or in any controls in schools or on teachers. This would mean that everything would depend on luck since every pupil would depend on the efficiency(实力),the ideal and the purpose of each teacher.
Without external examinations, employers will look for employees from the highly respected schools and from families known to them - a form of favoritism will replace equality. At the moment, the bright child from an ill - respected school can show certificates(证书)to prove he or she is suitable for a job, while the lack of a certificate shows the unsuitability of a dull child attending a well - respected school. This defense of excellence and opportunity would disappear if external examinations were taken away, and the bright child from a poor family would be a prisoner of his or her school's fame(名誉),unable to compete for employment with the child from the favored school.
The opponents(对手)of the examination system suggest that examinations are an evil force because they show differences between pupils. According to these people, there must be no special, different, academic class. They have even suggested that there should be no form of difference in sport or any other area: all jobs or posts should be filled by unsystematic selection. The selection would be made by people who themselves are probably selected by some computer.
These people are not just against school organization, but are at war with the whole idea of modem competitive society and they are using children in schools for their destructive(破坏性的)purposes. There is no reason why we should allow such people to determine the way our schools are organized when it is to the obvious disadvantage of the pupils, of the schools and of our society as a whole.

questions.text: According to the passage, the writer thinks that <blank>.

choices.A: changing the standards could mean the end of equality
choices.B: standards must keep changing in order to achieve equality
choices.C: there would be no standards without external examinations
choices.D: we cannot have standards because examinations are not perfect

questions.text: Which of the following sentences is TRUE?

choices.A: Most students from poor families can't get a good job.
choices.B: Some people are using students to destroy our society.

question_sets.context:
(A)
Each year several thousand people are killed on the road in Great Britain. Every year between one and two hundred thousand people are injured(伤害), or killed in road accidents.
If you are in England and if you listen to the eight o'clock news from BBC, you will often hear news of road accidents. You may hear something like this "On last Monday evening, at about twenty minutes to ten, a cyclist was knocked down by a truck at crossing of Oak Road and High Street in Croydon. The cyclist has died from his injuries. Anyone who saw the accident please communicate(联系)with New Scotland Yard, telephone number Whitehall one, two, one, two."
Accidents are often caused(引起)by carelessness. If everybody obeys the rules, the roads will be much safer. How can we make the road safer?
In Great Britain traffic keeps on to the left. Motor-cars, trucks, buses and cyclists must all keep to the left side of the road. In most other country traffic keeps to the right.
Before crossing the road, stop and look both ways. Look right, look left again. Then, if you are sure that the road is clear, that there is nothing coming, it is safe to cross the road. If you see small children, or very old people, or blind people, waiting to cross the road, it is kind act to help them to cross the road in safety.
We must teach young children to cross the road safely. We must always give them a good example. Small children mustn't play in the street.

questions.text: How many people are injured in Great Britain every year?

choices.B: Between one and two hundred people.

questions.explanation: According to the passage, between one and two hundred thousand people are injured or killed in road accidents every year in Great Britain.

questions.text: "New Scotland Yard" may be <blank>.

choices.D: a group saving people from road accidents

questions.explanation: New Scotland Yard is the headquarters of the Metropolitan Police in London, so it represents the police force.

questions.text: "In Great Britain traffic keeps to the left" means <blank>.

choices.A: all the cars, buses etc. coming and going along the road must be driven along the left side of the road.
choices.B: all the cars, buses etc. coming and going along the road must be driven to the left side of the road.
choices.C: only trucks must be driven along the left side of the road.
choices.D: all the cars, buses etc. coming and going along the road must be stopped on the left side of the road.

questions.explanation: The sentence means that all vehicles must drive on the left side of the road in Great Britain.

questions.text: In our country traffic should keep <blank>.
questions.explanation: Assuming 'our country' refers to China, traffic keeps to the right.

questions.text: Which of the following is right?

choices.A: Every road accident is caused by carelessness.
choices.B: "The road is clear," means "There's nothing on it."
choices.C: Before crossing the road in China, you should look left first and then look right.
choices.D: People can play in the street except small children.

questions.explanation: Look left first and then look right is the general rule in China. The passage says look right, look left again.

question_sets.context:
(B)
1970 World conservation(保护)year. The United Nations wanted everyone to know that the world was in danger. They hoped something could be done.
Here is one example of the problem. At one time there were 1,300 plants, trees and flowers in Holland, but now only 866 are left. The others have been destroyed by modern man and his science. We are changing the earth, the air, the water and everything around us. We can't live without these things. If things go on like this, we shall destroy ourselves.
What will happen in the future? Perhaps it is more important to ask "What must we do?" More and more young people have known this. Many of them are helping to save our world. For example, they plant trees. In a small town in United States a large group of girls cleaned the banks of 11 kilometers of their river. Young people may hear about conversation through a song called "no one's going to change our world". It was made by Cliff Richard and other singers. The money from it will help to conserve tigers, elephants and panders on the earth.

questions.text: The United Nations hoped something to be done <blank>.
questions.explanation: According to the first sentence of the passage, the United Nations wanted something to be done to conserve the world.

questions.text: Why aren't there so many plants, trees and flowers in Holland now? Because <blank>.

choices.A: people there didn't need so many plants, trees and flowers
choices.B: people there want to destroy themselves
choices.C: little conservation has been done there
choices.D: people need more land to live on

questions.explanation: From the passage, the plants, trees, and flowers have been destroyed by modern man and his science, meaning little conservation has been done there.

questions.text: How many plants, trees, and flowers have been destroyed in Holland?
questions.explanation: 1300 - 866 = 434 plants, trees, and flowers have been destroyed.

questions.text: We shall destroy ourselves if we go on <blank>.

choices.B: changing the earth, the air, and the water around us
choices.D: helping to conserve the tigers, elephants and pandas

questions.explanation: From the passage, 'We are changing the earth, the air, the water and everything around us. We can't live without these things. If things go on like this, we shall destroy ourselves.'

questions.text: What must we do now according to passage?

choices.B: Clean the banks of the rivers

questions.explanation: The passage asks 'What must we do?' which implies we must save the world.

question_sets.context:
(C)
Hearing the strange noise from the back of the car, the driver got out to have a look. He examined the wheels carefully but as he found nothing wrong, he continued his way. The noise began almost immediately and now it was louder than ever. Quickly turning his head, he saw where seemed to be a great black cloud following the car. When he stopped at a village further on, he was told that a queen bee must be hidden in his car as there were thousands of bees nearby.
The man drove away as quickly as possible, hoping to get rid of the bees. After an hour's hard driving, he stopped his car outside a hotel and went in to have a drink. He had hardly sat down when he was told that his car was covered with bees. The poor driver had to telephone the police for help. The police suggested calling a bee keeper, who found the unwelcome passengers hidden near the wheel at the back of the car. Very grateful to the driver for his unexpected gift, the keeper took the queen and her thousands of followers home in a large box.

questions.text: What is the main idea of this story?

choices.A: A bad thing can sometimes lead to good results.
choices.B: Hidden passengers like insects(昆虫)can sometimes cause a lot of trouble.
choices.C: A bee-keeper is good at solving difficult problems.

questions.explanation: Though the driver experienced trouble, the bee keeper was grateful. It shows that bad things can sometimes lead to good results.

questions.text: Why did the man check the wheels carefully?

choices.A: Because he was told that a queen bee must be hidden in his car.
choices.B: Because he realized that the wheels needed repairing.
choices.C: Because the strange noise came from the back of his car.
choices.D: Because he thought there must be something wrong with the wheels.

questions.explanation: The driver checked the wheels because he heard a strange noise from the back of the car and assumed something was wrong with the wheels.

questions.text: What did the man see when he turned his head? He saw <blank>.

choices.A: a great black cloud following his car
choices.B: something that looked like a big dark cloud
choices.D: a queen bee hiding near the wheels

questions.explanation: The passage states that he saw what 'seemed to be a great black cloud following the car', indicating it looked like a big dark cloud.

questions.text: Where did the driver see the hidden passenger?

choices.B: On his way to the village

questions.explanation: The bee keeper found the bees near the wheel at the back of the car when he stopped outside the hotel.

questions.text: Which sentence can be used to end the story with?

choices.A: The fact that a queen bee was hidden in the car proved to be true.
choices.B: To express his gratitude to the keeper, the driver drove him home.
choices.C: The man shook hands with the bee-keeper again and again and wrote a letter of thanks to the police.
choices.D: Very grateful too, the man drove away without the "black cloud" which had hung over his car.

questions.explanation: Ending with the driver driving away without the 'black cloud' provides a sense of closure.

question_sets.context:
Once Effendi had a joke with the Prime Minister (宰相). He said that the Minister would die the next day. The next day, the Minister fell to the ground from the horse and really died. When the king learned this, he got angry and sent his men to catch Effendi at once.
When Effendi was brought to him, the king shouted angrily, "Effendi, since (既然) you knew when my Minister would die, you must know the date of your own death (死) . Say it out, or you'll die today."
Effendi looked at the king for a while. Then he answered, "But how can I know? I'll die two days earlier than you." The king was afraid that if he killed Effendi, he himself would die after that. He thought he must keep Effendi alive (活着) as long as possible, so he let Effendi go.

questions.text: This story tells us ________.

choices.A: how Effendi fooled (愚弄) the king
choices.D: Effendi knew the dates of everyone's death

questions.explanation: The story primarily illustrates how Effendi tricked the king to save his own life.

questions.text: The Prime Minister died because ________.
questions.explanation: The text states the Minister died from falling off a horse.

questions.text: Why did the king ask Effendi to tell him the date of Effendi's own death?

choices.A: Because the king wanted to know when he himself would die.
choices.B: Because the wanted to find an excuse to kill Effendi.
choices.C: Because he himself had known the date of Effendi's death.
choices.D: Because he wanted to know when Effendi would die.

questions.explanation: The king wanted an excuse to execute Effendi for predicting the Minister's death.

questions.text: The king let Effendi go because ________.

choices.A: he hoped to live a long life
choices.C: he didn't believe (相信) Effendi's words
choices.D: He knew he would die two days later

questions.explanation: The king feared killing Effendi would lead to his own death soon after.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true?

choices.A: Effendi played a joke on the Minister
choices.B: The king was afraid of death.
choices.C: Effendi didn't know when the king would die.
choices.D: If the king killed Effendi, he himself would die two days later.

questions.explanation: Effendi claimed he would die two days before the king, not that the king would die two days after killing him.

question_sets.context:
There are many kinds of animals that live in the forest, such as mice, rabbits, squirrels, owls(猫头鹰)and hawks．Animals in the forest depend on one another for food．
Many small forest animals, such as mice, eat green plants for food, and then they, themselves, are eaten by larger animals．This is called a food chain．
A food chain begins with the sun．The green plants in the forest use the sun's energy(能源)to make food for themselves．This process, or action, is called photosynthesis(光合作用)．
Forest plants produce flowers and seeds that are eaten by mice and other animals．The mice get their energy from the plants, and the mice become food for a larger animal, such as the hunting hawk．So, the energy from the sun passes from the plants to the mice to the hawk．A break in any link of this food chain means that some animals may not have enough food to live．
Choose the best answers．

questions.text: Photosynthesis takes place when <blank>．

choices.B: green plants use the sun's energy to make food
choices.C: forest animals eat the food made by green plants

questions.explanation: Photosynthesis is the process where green plants use the sun's energy to make food.

question_sets.context:
Last month, Mr and Mrs Green moved. They are beginning to be very sorry that they ever did move. Their new mobile(可动的) home is large and nice. Why are they sorry they moved? They are fired of (厌倦) strangers walking into their new home. At all hours of the business day, people walk right in carrying letters and looking for the stamp machine. The people sometimes get angry when they can't find what they want.
The Greens' new mobile house is nice, but they have found that it has on problem. It used to be(曾经是) a post office. When the post office moved to another place, the Greens moved in. But many people didn't pay attention(注意) to it. They continued(继续) to come to the same old place to post their letters and buy stamps.

questions.text: When did the Greens move?
questions.explanation: The first sentence says, "Last month, Mr and Mrs Green moved."

questions.text: Mr and Mrs Green live <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage mentions that their new mobile home is large and nice.

questions.text: People looking for the post office <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage mentions that people sometimes get angry when they can't find what they want.

questions.text: Which happened first?

choices.A: The mobile home was a post office
choices.C: The people cam to the wrong place

questions.explanation: The passage says it 'used to be' a post office.

questions.text: The story tells us that people <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage says that people 'didn't pay attention' to the post office moving.

question_sets.context:
People can have heart problems. So can dogs. Ginger, a ten-year-old dog, had such a serious heart problem that her life was in danger. Ginger's owner, Mrs Brown, loved her dog very much and couldn't lose her.
The newspaper in the town, where Mrs Brown lived, carried a story about Ginger and her problem. A_manufacturer_of heart pacemakers(起搏器) came to save Ginger. Pacemakers are usually used for people, but the manufacturer gave one to help save the dog's life. The cost of the pacemaker would be 850 dollars, but Mrs Brown received one as a present. The doctor who_installed_the pacemaker in Ginger was a veterinarian(兽医). Ginger was operated on for 45 minutes, and Mrs Brown hoped that the dog would be able to live a healthy life.
Pacemakers are often used to help people with heart problems, but an operation like this is quite unusual for an animal. A pacemaker is installed to help regulate(调节) the heartbeat(心跳). For a heart that beats weakly, the pacemaker helps keep a strong beat.

questions.text: A heart problem almost <blank>.
questions.explanation: The first paragraph says, "Ginger... had such a serious heart problem that her life was in danger."

questions.text: A_manufacturer_of pacemakers <blank>.
questions.explanation: A manufacturer is someone who produces or makes something.

questions.text: Few animals have pacemakers because the pacemakers <blank>.
questions.explanation: While not directly stated, it can be inferred that cost is a factor, as the operation is described as unusual.

questions.text: Something that's_installed_is <blank>.
questions.explanation: 'Installed' means to put something in position for use.

questions.text: The newspaper story caused(made happen) <blank>.

choices.B: veterinarians to be out of work

questions.explanation: The newspaper story led to the manufacturer providing a pacemaker.

question_sets.context:
What do we know about the sea? Most of us have seen it. We know that it looks very beautiful when the sun is lighting on it. We also know that it can be less beautiful when the weather is terrible(可怕的). What other things do we know about it?
The first thing is that the sea is very big. Look at a map of the world and you'll find there is less land than sea. The sea covers 3/4 of the world. The sea is very deep in some places. Some parts of the sea are very shallow(浅的). At a place near Japan, the sea is nearly 11 kilometres deep! If we put the highest mountain in the world into the sea at that place, there would be two kilometres of water above it.

questions.text: Which of the following is true according to the passage?

choices.C: The sea always looks both beautiful and terrible when it is fine.
choices.D: The sea doesn't look  beautiful all the time.

questions.explanation: The passage states that the sea can be less beautiful when the weather is terrible.

questions.text: What will you find if you look at a map of the world? We'll find<blank>.

choices.A: there's much more water than land
choices.B: the sea covers 3/4 of the land
choices.C: the land covers 1/3 of the sea

questions.explanation: The passage says there is less land than sea, implying more water.

questions.text: This passage tells us that <blank>.

choices.C: the sea is shallow and deep, too
choices.D: the depths(深度) of the sea in different places are quite different

questions.explanation: The passage says the sea is deep in some places and shallow in others.

questions.text: The word "it" in the last sentence of this passage means <blank>.
questions.explanation: The last sentence talks about putting the highest mountain into the sea.

questions.text: The best title (题目) for this passage is <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage gives a general overview of the sea, making 'Something About The Sea' the best title.

question_sets.context:
Tom saw an advertisement(广告)in a newspaper for a beautiful modern bicycle. It cost(值)55 pounds(英镑). So he went to the shop and asked to see one of the wonderful bicycles.
The shopkeeper was very happy to show one to Tom. Tom had a look at it carefully, then turned to the shopkeeper and said, "there isn't a lamp on this bicycle, but there was one on the bicycle in your advertisement."
"Yes, sir," answered the man, "but the lamp isn't included(包括)in the price(价钱) of the bicycle ."
"Not included in the price of the bicycle?" Tom said angrily. "But that's not honest. If the lamp is in the advertisement, it should be included in the price."
"Well, sir, " answered the shopkeeper coldly, "there is also a girl on the bicycle in the advertisement, but we can not give you a girl with the bicycle, either."

questions.text: In the advertisement, there was a <blank> and a <blank> on the bicycle.
questions.explanation: The advertisement had a lamp and a girl on the bicycle.

questions.text: After he read the advertisement, Tom decided to <blank>.
questions.explanation: Tom went to the shop to look at the bicycle.

questions.text: Tom <blank> after he looked at the bike carefully.

choices.A: returned the bike to the shopkeeper
choices.B: didn't find a lamp on the bicycle
choices.C: showed the bike to the shopkeeper

questions.explanation: Tom noticed the bike did not have a lamp.

questions.text: Tom thought it was <blank> for the shopkeeper to sell the bike without a lamp while there was one in the advertisement.
questions.explanation: Tom felt it was dishonest to sell the bike without the lamp advertised.

questions.text: The text gives us a lesson that <blank>.

choices.A: we must read a newspaper carefully.
choices.B: bicycles must be looked at  carefully before they are bought
choices.C: we can't completely(完全地) believe(相信) an advertisement sometimes
choices.D: the price of something is often changed(改变)

questions.explanation: The story illustrates that advertisements can be misleading.

question_sets.context: One evening two young men were walking in the street together. They tried to find a chance to steal something. The clock struck twelve. Most of the people went to bed. Quickly they came to a house and it seemed that everyone in the house had fallen asleep. Standing at the front gate, one said in English to the other in a low voice, "You wait here. I'll go around to the back door and then get into the house." Suddenly out of the house ran a dog, barking at them. The two men were very frightened and ran away as fast as they could. Finally, they stopped at a lonely place. The man said breathlessly, "It's too bad. I haven't expected(预料)that the dog could understand English."

questions.text: Why did the two men walk in the street one evening? Because <blank>.

choices.C: they would like to take a walk
choices.D: they went to visit their friends

questions.explanation: The passage clearly states that 'They tried to find a chance to steal something'.

questions.text: "One said in English to the other in a low voice." From the sentence we know <blank>.

choices.D: he was afraid of waking up others

questions.explanation: Speaking in a low voice suggests he didn't want to be heard, implying he was afraid of waking people up.

questions.text: The dog ran out of the house and barked at them only because <blank>.
questions.explanation: Dogs bark at strangers or when they detect someone outside.

questions.text: At last the two young men <blank>.
questions.explanation: They ran away without stealing anything.

questions.text: What did the owners do while the dog was barking?
questions.explanation: The passage doesn't provide any information about what the owners did.

question_sets.context:
Are you looking for something fun and would you like to help other people in your spare time? Then join us and be an volunteer!
We are a non-profit organization. We have volunteer jobs for people of all ages. Anyone, from twelve-year-old children to people in their 80s, can become a volunteer.
You can help people in many ways. Schools need help with taking care of children while parents are working. Hospitals need volunteers to look after children while their parents see a doctor. Animal lovers can help take care of those dogs and cats without homes. There is something for everyone.
"As a volunteer, I don't want to get anything. Seeing the children's happy faces, I am happy, too." Said Caros Dimingo, an old woman of 62.
"I often play with computer games in my spare time before. Now I help older people learn how to use computers." Said another volunteer at the age of 18.
If everyone helps out a bit, we'll all have a better world to live in.
Interested? Call us on 1―800―555―5756. Or visit our website: activol.com.

questions.text: Which kind of people can become volunteers?

choices.B: People from 12 years old to about 80.

questions.explanation: The passage states, 'Anyone, from twelve-year-old children to people in their 80s, can become a volunteer.'

questions.text: <blank> need volunteers.
questions.explanation: Volunteers can help 'take care of those dogs and cats without homes'.

questions.text: Volunteers want to get <blank> when they help others.
questions.explanation: Carlos Dimingo says, 'As a volunteer, I don't want to get anything.'

questions.text: Carlos Domingo does volunteer work with <blank>.
questions.explanation: Carlos Dimingo says, 'Seeing the children's happy faces, I am happy, too.'

questions.text: This passage is <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage promotes volunteering and includes contact information.

question_sets.context:
Everyone knows London is an important city in England. London was once the biggest city in the world, but now there are many cities which are much bigger than it. London has a population of about 7,000,000 now. It is an old city and is famous for many things. Many tourists come from all over the world to visit its famous buildings and hear the famous clock, Big Ben.
Like many big cities, London has problems with traffic and pollution. Over one million people use the London underground(地铁)every day, but there are still too many cars in the streets. The air isn't clean, but it is cleaner than it was 100 years ago.
Perhaps the best things about London are the parks. There are five in the center of the city. But for the children, their favourite place is Hamleys, the biggest toy shop in the world. They can buy the good toys there.

question_sets.context:
Our village carpenter(木匠), John Bill, came one day and made a dining table for my wife．He made it just the right size to fill the space between the two windows．When I got home that evening, John was drinking a cup of tea and writing out his bill(账单) for the job．
My wife said to me, quietly, "That's his ninth cup of tea today．" But she said, in a loud voice, "It's a beautiful table, dear, isn't it?"
"I'll decide on that when I see the bill．" I said．
One dining table       10 November 1989
Cost(成本)of wood      $17.00
Paint            $1.50
Work, 8 hours($1 an hour)  $8.00
Total(合计)         $36.50
When 1 was looking at the bill, John said, "It's been ft．fine day, hasn't it? Quite sunny．"
"Yes," I said, "I'm glad it Js only the l0th of November．''"Me, too," said John．"You wait―it'11 be a lot colder by the end of the month．''
"Yes．Colder and more expensive! Dining tables will be $20 more expensive on November 30th, won't they, John?"
John looked hard at me for half a minute．Was there a little smile in his two blue eyes? I gave his bill back to him．"If it isn't too much trouble, John," I said, "Please add it up again．You can forget the date…"
I paid him $26.50 and he was happy to get it．

choices.B: Because it was really a fine day．
choices.C: Because he wanted the writer to check the bill carefully．
choices.D: Because he wanted to tell the writer what the weather was like．

choices.B: Because paint would be more expensive．
choices.C: Because the cost of wood would be more expensive．
choices.D: Because he thought John would almost certainly add the date to the cost of the dining table．

questions.explanation: The writer hinted that John was trying to cheat by adding an extra $20 for making the table on November 10th.

questions.explanation: The writer thought John would add $20 to the original total cost of $36.50, which would make it $56.50.

choices.A: John made a mistake in the bill
choices.B: John tried to fool the writer in order to get more money for his work
choices.C: John had written out the bill before the writer got home
choices.D: John still wanted to get$36.50 for his work in the end

questions.explanation: John was trying to fool the writer by adding an extra $20 to the bill, but the writer noticed it.

question_sets.context:
History, as we know, is filled with facts, with places, names, dates, and events．
History is also filled with feelings, with pain, joy, excitement, and fear．
Facts are set down in books, but what happens to feelings? How can you take the pain, for example, and write it into a history book? You can't．But you can put it to music．Take the _blues_, for example．
The blues started when black musicians in the South began to sing about their hard times, those times which made them feel _blue_．The early blues was the beginning of other musical styles, from jazz to rock and roll．
Music, you might say, is a record of feelings．
Of course, facts are important: the civil rights movement, the race for space, the Vietnam War．
But the feelings behind these events―the pride of being black, the excitement of a rocket blast(点火起飞), the pain of a war―are also an important part of history．

questions.text: In the passage, the word"blue"and the word"blues"are related to <blank>．

choices.A: a feeling and a kind of music
choices.C: a kind of music and a person

questions.explanation: 'Blue' represents a feeling of sadness, while 'blues' is a genre of music.

questions.text: According to the writer's idea, what can make people feel blue?
questions.explanation: The passage states that the blues started when black musicians began to sing about their hard times, which made them feel blue.

questions.text: Besides the above, the writer also explains <blank>．

choices.B: the relation between history and music
choices.C: the feelings behind some important events

questions.explanation: The passage discusses the importance of feelings behind historical events.

question_sets.context:
Shopping habits in the United States have changed greatly in the last quarter of the twentieth century．Early in the 1900s, most American towns and cities had a Main Street．Main Street was always in the heart of a town．This street was lined on both sides with many businesses．Here, shoppers walked into stores to look at au kinds of merchandise(商品): clothing, furniture, hardware(五金), groceries(杂货)．In addition, some shops offered services．These shops included drugstores(药店), restaurants, shoe―repair stores, and barber or hairdressing shops(理发店)．But in the 1950s, a change began to take place．Too many cars and trucks had crowded into Main Street．There were few parking places．Because the streets were crowded, merchants(商人) began to look with interest at the open spaces outside the city limits．Open space is what their car―driving customers needed. And open space is what they got when the first shopping center was built．Shopping centers, or malls, started as a collection of small new stores built away from crowded city centers．Attracted by hundreds of free parking spaces, customers were drawn away from downtown areas to the outlying malls．
By the late 1970s, many shopping malls had almost developed into small cities themselves．In addition to providing the Convenience of one―stop shopping, malls were changed into landscaped parks, with beautiful flowers, fountains, and outdoor entertainment．For example, one of the shopping malls is The Galleria in Houston, Texas．Inside the Galleria, more than tens of shops face balconies and there is an indoor ice skating rink(溜冰场)．Some of Houston's best restaurants are also here．Atop(在……顶上)the whole mammoth(巨大的) structure is a new hotel．The Galleria, and other imaginative shopping centers throughout the United States, have led a magazine to title its recent leading article "The Mailing of America"

choices.B: Before the 1950s, a Main Street was a shopping center in most American towns．
choices.C: Main Street was usually in the heart of a town．
choices.D: At the beginning of the twentieth century.all kinds of stores were located along Main Street．

questions.explanation: The passage states that during the 1950s, there were few parking places on Main Street, so A is not correct.

questions.explanation: The passage describes the Galleria as a shopping mall.

questions.explanation: The passage discusses the changes in American shopping centers, from Main Street to shopping malls.

question_sets.context:
Come with Me, Sir Henry Smith taught science at the City School. Once he wentto a bookstore and bought some books, most of which were expensive (昂贵的) ones. He left them in his car in a quiet street. Then he went and bought some other things at other shops. At six o'clock he came back to the car. One window was open, and the books were gone! Henry drove back to his home in Lake Street. That night he wrote a letter to a newspaper. The next day he went to the police. On Friday people read an advertisement (广告) in the newspaper:
BOOKS WANTED
Have you any books that you no longer want? I buy old and modern books. Open all day on Saturdays. Smith, 18 Lake Street. Henry stayed at home on Saturday. His first visitor came at eight o'clock. Henry took him to the kitchen (厨房) . At half past nine another man arrived. He had a bag under his arm.
"Mr. Smith?" the man asked. "That's right," Henry said. "Can I help you?" "I have some good books. You buy books, don't you?" "Yes. Bring them in. I'll have a look at them." Soon the books were on the dining-table (餐桌) . "Come in now," Henry called out, "and bring the list." A policeman came into the dining-room. He read the titles (书名) on the books and then those on the list in his hand. They were the same. "Come with me, sir," the policeman said to the man.

choices.D: He took them from a car.

question_sets.context: The air around us is important to everyone. Without air, we couldn't live. Everyone understands that. Without air, there would be no fire. There would be no cars, cars need air to start. Without air, there would be no wind or clouds. There would be no weather, as we know it. the night time would be very cold and the days very hot. We would have to look for shelter(遮蔽)from the sun, as there would be no atmosphere(大气)to protect(保护)us from the sun's deadly rays(光线).

question_sets.context: Each morning a rich man found a poor man sitting on a park bench(长凳). The poor man always sat there, looking at the big hotel in which the rich man lived. One day the rich man got out of his car and said to the poor man, "Excuse me, but I just want to know why you sit here and look at my hotel every morning." "Sir," said the poor man, "I am a failure. I have no money, no home. I sleep on this bench, and every night I dream(梦想)that one day I'll sleep in that hotel." The rich man said, "Tonight your dream will come true. I'll pay for the best room in that hotel for you a whole month."A few days later, the rich man went by the poor man's room to ask him how he was enjoying himself. To his surprise, he found that the man had moved out of the hotel, back to his park bench. When the rich man asked why, the poor man said, "You see, when I'm down here sleeping on my bench, I dream I'm up there, in that big hotel. It's a wonderful dream. But when I was up there, I dreamed I was back to this cold bench. It was a terrible dream, and I couldn't get any sleep at all."

Harry Potter returns!
KIDS make different wishes for the new year. Some hope that the days will pass by more quickly. Why? Because they are waiting to read a new book, "Harry Potter and the Half-blood Prince"!
It is the sixth book in the Harry Potter stories. It will be in bookstores in Britain and the US on July 16,2005. Chinese kids will be able to read it three months later.

An old porter (搬运工人) had worked for the railway for a very long time. One morning he was standing in one of the big railway stations and waiting for travelers to ask him to help them with their luggage, when he saw a small man running toward the trains with a big bag in his hand.
The porter watched the man for a few seconds, and the man saw the porter.
At once the small man ran up the porter and said, "Can I catch the 10:35 train to London, porter?" He was breathing very fast, and he seemed worried.
The old porter looked at him for a moment and then said with a smile, "Well, sir, I'd like to help you, but I can't answer your question because I don't know how fast you can run along rails. You see, " he explained, "the 10:35 train to London left five minutes ago."

question_sets.context:
It seems to be strange to most of you that there is a blind spot (盲点) on your eyes. Here is an interesting experiment that can make something disappear, when one eye is open.
Make a card about the size of a postcard and write two English letters L and R on it, L on the left and R on the right. First, hold the card about 80cm away and you see both the letters. Then close your right eye and look at the letter R only with your left eye. And now, as you moved the card slowly towards you, you'll find the letter L disappearing. But if you move the card nearer to your face, the letter will be seen again. Now do the same experiment with your left eye closed, you'll find the letter R disappearing.
Why does the letter disappear? It is because there is a blind spot on the eyes. When the image (影像) of the letter falls on the blind spot, it won't be seen. That is why either of the letters disappears.

questions.text: You fail to see the letter L in the experiment because <blank>.

choices.B: its image falls on the blind spot
choices.C: you move it close to your eye

questions.explanation: The text says that 'When the image (影像) of the letter falls on the blind spot, it won't be seen'.

③. Close your right eye.
④. Write two English letters.
⑤. Look at the letter R.
⑥. Make a card.
questions.explanation: First, make a card. Then, write two letters on it. Next, hold the card. Then, close your right eye. Finally, look at the letter R.

choices.D: how to find the blind spot

questions.explanation: The passage mainly tells us that there is a blind spot on the eyes.

question_sets.context:
A great thinker and teacher
Who is the greatest teacher In Chinese history? You can't think of anyone else when you hear people read Confucius' 2500-year-old words: "All study but no thinking makes people puzzled. All thinking but no study makes people lazy."
Who's Confucius?
He was born on September 28,551 BC in Kingdom of Lu, in today's Shangdong Province.
Chinese see Confucius as the greatest thinker and also the greatest teacher. He had about 3000 students.
For more than 2000 years, Conficius' ideas have been around in people's everyday lives. Now they have gone far into east and south Asia. People can still hear them today.
Why are his ideas so popular? They help not only in everyday life but also in society.
Confucius' most important ideas are kindness and good manners.
Confucius said young people should take care of the old. People should give up thinking of themselves and work for others.
As a great teacher, Confucius said all should go to school if they could and wanted to learn.
Some of Confucius' popular words are: "A kind person should care for others" and "be strict with yourself, but be kind to others".
People use his ideas to help themselves and society.
Now, more than 100 Internet websites are teaching people about him.
"Kindness and honesty are the best values of the world today," said 79-year-old Kong Fanjin. He is studying Confucius.

questions.text: Which sentence means "思而不学则怠"?

choices.A: All study but no thinking makes people puzzled
choices.B: All thinking but no study makes people lazy.
choices.C: A kind person should care for others.
choices.D: Be strict with yourself, but be kind to others.

questions.explanation: All thinking but no study makes people lazy

questions.explanation: They help not only in everyday life but also in society.

Then he went out and began to look for it in the street . Just then a friend came along ." What's the matter with you ?'' asked his friend ." I'm looking for my ring . I lost it in my house .'' " You lost your ring in your house , but you are looking for it in the street . How foolish it is ! " But it is dark in my house . I shall never find it there . But here in the street , it is much brighter . I can see everything .

question_sets.context:
Many people like to watch TV . Watching TV is one of the most important activities of the day . TV brings the outside closer to people's homes . Some people say that the world is smaller than before because of TV .
What's going on in the other countries ? How do people live in places far away ? Is there a good sports game somewhere ? What's life in the deepest part of the sea ?
If you want to answer these and other kinds of questions , just turn on the TV . Turn it on and watch . You can see a lot and learn a lot . Of course , people can also learn through reading or listening to the radio . But with TV they can learn better and more easily . Why ? Because they can hear and watch , too .
TV helps to open our eyes . TV also helps to open our minds . TV often gives us new ideas . We learn newer and better ways of doing something .

question_sets.context:
On Christmas Eve ----the night before Christmas Day , children all over Britain put a stocking at the end of their beds before they go to sleep . Their parents usually tell them that Father Christmas will come during the night .
Father Christmas is very kind―hearted . He lands on top of each house and climbs down the chimney into the fireplace . He fills each of the stocking with Christmas presents .
Of course . Father Christmas isn't real . In Jim and Kate's house ," Father Christmas ''is really Mr Green doesn't climb down the chimney . He waits until the children are asleep . Then he quietly goes into their bedrooms , and fills their stockings with small presents . When they were very young , Mr Green sometimes dressed up in a red coat . But he doesn't do that now . The children are no longer young , and they know who " Father Christmas ''really is . But they still put their stocking at the end of their beds .

questions.explanation: The passage states: 'Christmas Eve ----the night before Christmas Day'.

questions.explanation: Parents fill stockings after the children are asleep.

question_sets.context:
In July, 2001, Zhang Jian, a 37-year-old swimmer landed in Calais, France after swimming for twelve hours. He became the first Chinese ever to cross the English Channel. The 33.8-kilometre channel has attracted many swimmers because it is one of the most difficult channels to cross.
Zhang Jian set off at 1: 30 p.m. on July 29, 2001. After putting some oil on his skin to help keep warm, he stepped into the sea from Shakespeare Beach, Dover.  Most of the time, Zhang swam freestyle to save energy. But he had to change his style along the way because the ocean currents changed every six hours and the water was so cold. During the crossing he ate some food and had some drinks. About three hours before he landed in Calais, a British guide jumped into the sea and swam together with him. The next day, Zhang walked onto the French beach at last.

questions.explanation: He was 37 in 2001, now it's two years later.

questions.explanation: Shakespeare Beach, Dover is in England.

questions.explanation: The passage indicates that the English Channel has attracted many swimmers.

choices.A: when Zhang Jian crossed the English Channel

questions.explanation: The passage focuses on the process and details of Zhang Jian's crossing.

question_sets.context:
Milk was one of the main human foods long before history was written. It will probably remain one as long as there are animals that give milk.
The old word "milk" came from Sanskrit (梵文), one of the oldest languages known to man. A very old picture of milking animals has been found. It was drawn five thousand years ago. People got their milk from their own animals. But in modem times new inventions made the milk industry (工业) a big business. In 1851 Gall Borden found a way to take some of the water from milk. This made it keep longer. Four years later, Louis Pasteur introduced a way to kill the bacteria (细菌) in milk. So in the same year a special milk bottle was made. This was followed by the invention of machines that could fill bottles with milk.
These discoveries meant that milk could be stored longer.
Some people believe that milk drinking will become less popular than it has been. But remember how long milk has been an important food and think of the many ways in which it is useful. It seems safe to say that milk industry will always be important.

questions.explanation: According to the passage, milk was a staple food before history was written.

questions.explanation: The passage states that Sanskrit is one of the oldest languages known to man.

questions.explanation: The passage states that killing bacteria made milk keep longer.

questions.text: When was the special milk bottle made?
questions.explanation: The passage states that Louis Pasteur introduced a way to kill bacteria in milk, and in the same year (1855), a special milk bottle was made.

questions.text: This passage mainly tells us <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage provides a general overview of milk's history, production, and importance.

question_sets.context: You have heard of Webster Toys. Webster have made good, safe, interesting toys for more than a hundred years. Now, we sell them, and children play with them, in countries from New Zealand to Norway and from Japan to Brazil. We are looking for someone to sell our toys in the Far East. He or she, should be between the ages of thirty and forty. He should already have some years of selling experience in world markets. He should speak English well, and at least one other Far Eastern language. The person we are looking for would live in Singapore and work in one office there, but he must travel for up to six months a year. He should know the Far East quite well. He should know how to sell in established markets and where to find new ones. He should understand money and make more than ever before, for himself and for Webster Toys. Webster want someone who can stand on his own feet. If you think you are the person we are looking for, write to Mr. J. Sloman at our Head Office.

Before you leave school , you will learn only one thousand or more.The words you know are called your vocabulary. You should try to make your vocabulary bigger. Read as many books as you can. There are a lot of books written in easy English for you to read. You will enjoy them. When you meet a new word , find it in your dictionary. question_sets.context:
To find out whether bees can see colors, the following experiment is made.
A table is put in a garden, and on the table is a blue card with some sugar on it. As soon
as one bee finds the sugar, many more come to it one after another in a short time. It seems
that one bee is able to tell the news of food to the other bees in their "home". After a moment,
the blue card with sugar on it is taken away. Instead of this card, another blue card is now put
on the left side of the first feeding place and a red card to its right. Nothing can be seen on the
two cards. Very soon bees arrive again, and fly towards the blue card. No bees go to the red
card.

question_sets.context:
She is a cute, quiet girl. As a daughter, she has no secrets from her mother, who is very pleased with her. But recently she has become somewhat mysterious, and not so open as before. She has a diary that she keeps under lock and key. Her mother cannot help worrying about her: what if she falls in love, which is too early for a girl of her age? After all she is reaching the "dangerous stage". These thoughts have caused trouble in the mother's mind.
One weekend the girl came to tell her mother that she was going to the cinema with her schoolmate and would return late. This was the first time her mother agreed, and she couldn't help worrying because her daughter had never been away at night before. The mother waited till nine and her uneasiness got the upper hand over her. She decided to go out to meet her daughter. Just at that moment the noise of a car pulling up drew her to the window and ――there was her daughter, waving goodbye to a boy. Her heart missed a beat. When the girl came in, the mother was watching TV, pretending nothing had happened. "Mum, I'm back." "Yeah." "Sorry to be late. Still sitting up?" "Yes. Oh, that …. Who's that boy?" The daughter was stunned for a moment. "Ah. It's my monitor. He gave me a lift on his way home. Mum, I'm going to bed." "All right. Go to sleep early."
The next morning when the mother went to the daughter's room to do some tidying, she found her diary left at her pillow. After a few minutes' hesitation she finally opened it to the entry of the night before. It read: Mum, it's love that made you ask, but it would show your understanding of me if you hadn't.
Holding the diary, the mother fell into thought.

e. Her mother worried about her daughter's returning late.
questions.explanation: 根据故事，正确的顺序是：她和她的同学去看电影。她母亲担心她回来晚了。她搭了她班长的车回来。她母亲假装看电视。她在日记里给她的母亲写信。

question_sets.context:
When someone says "Well, I guess I'll have to go to face the music", it does not mean he is planning to go to a concert. It is something far less pleasant, like being called in by your boss to explain why you did this or that, and why you did not do this or that. Sour music, indeed, but it has to be faced.
The phrase "to face the music" is familiar to every American, young and old. It is at least 100 years old. Where did the expression come from?
The first information comes from the American writer James Fenimore Cooper. He said ――in 1851 ――that the expression was first used by actors while waiting in the wings to go on stage. After they got their cue to go on, they often said, "It's time to go to face the music." And that is exactly what they did――face the orchestra(交响乐团) which was just below the stage.
An actor might be frightened or nervous as he moved on to the stage in front of the audience that might be friendly or perhaps unfriendly, especially if he forgot his lines. But he had to go out.
So, "to face the music" came to mean having to go through something, no matter how unpleasant the experience might be, because you knew you had no choice.
The other explanation comes from the army. Men had to face inspection(检阅) by their leader. The soldiers worried about how well they looked. Was their equipment(装备) clean――shiny enough to pass inspection? Still, the men had to go out, and face the music of the band, as well as the inspection. What else could they do?

question_sets.context:
It is five o'clock in the evening when Sally comes home from the office．She walks into the living room and looks at her three children．The children are fourteen,thirteen and nine years o1d．They are watching TV．
The living room is dirty and untidy．There are empty glasses and dirty clothes on the floor．There are cakes on the sofa.Games and toys are everywhere．
Sally is unhappy．"How dirty and untidy this place is!"She tells her children,"I can't work all day and then do housework all evening．I'm not going to do housework!"
And so,Sally doesn't do housework．She doesn't clean．She doesn't do the dishes．She doesn't wash clothes．Every evening she sits on the sofa and watches TV．
After two weeks,every dish in the house is dirty.All the children's clothes are dirty,too．Every garbage can(垃圾桶)is full．The house dirty and untidy．
Then,one day Sally comes home from work and gets a big surprise．The kitchen(厨房)is clean．The children cleaned the kitchen!
The next day,the living room is clean,and the children are washing their clothes．
Sally tells her children,"OK,I'll do housework again．But you have to help me．"
Now Sally and her three children do the housework together．Then they all sit on the sofa and watch TV!

question_sets.context:
There was an old pear tree in a man's garden．In the past,the tree fruited every year,so the man would get many pears．But now,the tree got old．There were no more pears for the man．So the ungrateful (忘恩负义的) man decided to cut the tree down．When he walked to the tree with an axe (斧子) in his hand,the tree said to him,"Please don't cut me down．I have brought so many pears for you in the past years．Now I only have a short time to live．"
"I'm sorry．I have to do so,"the man said,"because I need something to make a chair．" Then he began to wave his axe．At that moment,a bird in the old tree said to him,"Don't cut it  down! Every time you go out and your wife feels lonely,she will come out to the garden and sit under the tree to enjoy its cool shade (树荫),and I sing songs to make her happy．We give much pleasure to your wife when you are away from home．"
The man didn't listen to the bird and drove it away．When he was about to cut the tree,some bees flew out of it and said,"Listen! If you agree not to kill this tree,we will give you delicious  honey every day．Would you please leave the tree with us?"
The man got moved (感动)．He said,"You are so kind to the tree,although it has become
old．Now I see that I shouldn't cut it down．It has done so much to me and my wife．Let the
tree stay here,and let the bird_continue_to sing songs here．"With these words,the man left．
And the old tree lived there to its last day．

questions.text: Which can be the best title (标题) of the story?
questions.explanation: The story is mainly about the old tree and its fate, so 'The Old Tree' is the most fitting title.

choices.B: The man needed wood to make a chair．
choices.C: The tree didn't give any shade．
choices.D: The man couldn't get any pears from it．

questions.explanation: Although the man said he wanted to make a chair, the primary reason stated in the passage is that the tree no longer produced pears.

questions.explanation: "Continue" means to keep doing sth.

choices.C: Old people are kind and friendly．
choices.D: Birds and bees are always helpful．

questions.explanation: The man wants to cut down the tree because the tree can no longer fruit, so the story wants to tell us people should never be ungrateful.

question_sets.context:
Once there was no zero. To write sixty--three, people wrote 63. To write six hundred and three, people wrote 63. The space was there to mean "not any" tens. Sometimes people did not remember the space. It was hard to see and to read.
Later, people used a dot(点) to hold the space. Six hundred and three looked like 6・3. But the dot was also difficult to see, so people put a circle around it like 6⊙3. Then people could see the dot. They remember the space.
At last, only the circle around the dot was used. It was like a zero. This is one story of how the zero came to be used.

questions.text: As the space was difficult to see, <blank>.

choices.A: nothing should be done to change it.
choices.B: people refused(拒绝) to read it
choices.D: the zero couldn't be used any more

questions.explanation: The passage states that people sometimes did not remember the space because it was hard to see.

questions.text: What was the space in the number (数字) 6 3 for?
questions.explanation: The passage mentions that the space was there to mean 'not any' tens.

questions.text: The word in the story that looks like a circle and means "not any" is <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage explains that the circle around the dot eventually became the zero.

questions.text: From the story we can see <blank>.

choices.A: people long ago didn't understand how to make dots.
choices.C: people enjoyed telling stories about zero.
choices.D: the zero is hard to see and to read.

questions.explanation: The story implies that zero is essential for numerical representation.

questions.text: The title (题目) of the story can be <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage describes the evolution and origin of zero.
