question_sets.context:
How much sleep do we need? We are all different. Some people need only three hours of sleep a night. Others need ten hours of sleep a night. Most Americans sleep an average (平均)of seven to eight hours a night .After age fifty, the average sleep time goes down to 6.5 hours a night.
About one in three Americans has a problem with sleep. Many of these people can not fall asleep. The name of this problem is insomnia.
This is not a new problem. Many famous people in history had insomnia. Some of these people had special ideas to make them sleep. Benjamin Franklin, the famous statesman and inventor had for beds. He moved from one to the other to sleep. King Louis XII of France had 413 beds and hoped to fall asleep in one of them. Mark Twain, the famous writer, had a different way. He lay on his side across the end of the bed!

questions.explanation: The first paragraph states: "Most Americans sleep an average of seven to eight hours a night."

questions.explanation: Mark Twain was a famous writer, not a statesman. Benjamin Franklin was the statesman.

questions.explanation: The passage primarily discusses sleep and related issues, making 'sleep' the most appropriate title.

question_sets.context:
Life in the twenty-first century will be very different from life today. Between then and now many changes will take place, but what will the changes be?
The population is growing fast. There will be a large number of people in the world and most of them will live longer than people live now.
Computers will be much smaller and more useful, and there will be at least one in every home. And computer studies will be one of the important subjects in schools then.
People will work fewer hours than they do now and they will have more free time for sports, watching TV and traveling. Traveling will be much easier and cheaper. And many more people will go to other countries for holidays.
There will be changes in our food, too. Maybe no one will eat meat every day. Instead they eat more fruits and vegetables. People will be much healthier.
Work in the future will be different, too. Dangerous and hard work can be done by robots. Because of this, many people will not have enough work to do. This will be a problem.

questions.explanation: The passage says 'There will be a large number of people in the world'.

choices.A: go to other countries for holidays

questions.explanation: The passage says 'And many more people will go to other countries for holidays'.

questions.explanation: The passage says 'Instead they eat more fruits and vegetables'.

questions.explanation: The passage says 'Dangerous and hard work can be done by robots'.

choices.B: It will be much smaller and more useful for people

choices.D: It will be bigger and a lot of people will use it.

questions.explanation: The passage says 'Computers will be much smaller and more useful'.

question_sets.context:
An invention in front of your eyes
What is the most important invention of all time? Is it the written word that helps us to record information? Is it the telephone that lets us talk to people from all over the world? Is it the car that lets us travel at great speeds to meet others? Umberto Eco, an Italian writer, thinks it is something quite different. He says the most important invention might be right in front of your eyes. He is talking about a simple pair of glasses. Modern eye glasses were invented around 1000 years ago. They were more than just a conventient way to read. Before glasses, writers, scientists or teachers who could not see properly had to memorize everything. After about ten years of poor eyesight, they could not remember well enough and could not work. Glasses meant that people could work into their old age. People who wanted to remember some information could write it down and read it. Eye glasses are one of the world's greatest inventions and were probably worn by the people who designed the first telephones and cars.

choices.B: we need it to record information
choices.C: we just need it to read

questions.explanation: According to the passage, the written word helps us record information.

questions.explanation: The author thinks a simple pair of glasses is the greatest invention.

questions.text: Before glasses were invented, writers, scientists and teachers had to <blank>.
questions.explanation: Before glasses, writers, scientists or teachers had to memorize everything.

choices.A: People could not remember well enough
choices.C: People could write down some information and read it

questions.explanation: After glasses were invented, people could write down some information and read it.

choices.A: modern eye glasses were invented 100 years ago
choices.B: people who designed the first telephones and cars probably wore those glasses
choices.C: the author of this article is an American

questions.explanation: Eye glasses were probably worn by the people who designed the first telephones and cars.

question_sets.context:
A man once had a dream about the Black Forest in Germany. In his dream he was walking in the forest when two men ran out and tried to throw him to the ground. He ran off as fast as he could, but they followed him. He reached a place where he saw two roads in front of him, one to the right and the other to the left. Which road should he take? He heard the two men behind him, getting nearer, and at the same time he heard a voice in his ear. It told him to go to the right, and he did so. He ran on and soon came to a small hotel. He was received there kindly and given a room, and he was saved from the two men. That was the dream.
Twenty years later he was really in the Black Forest and, as happened in the dream long ago, two men ran out and tried to throw him down. He ran off, and came to a place with two roads, like in the dream. He remembered the dream and took the road to the right. He soon reached a small hotel, was taken in, and so was safe. His dream of twenty years before had saved his life.

questions.text: The Black Forest is __________.
questions.explanation: According to the first sentence, the Black Forest is in Germany.

questions.text: When he was walking in the forest, _______ ran after him.
questions.explanation: The passage says 'two men ran out and tried to throw him to the ground'.

questions.text: Finally he came to __________.
questions.explanation: The passage says 'He ran on and soon came to a small hotel'.

questions.text: It was _________ that saved the man's life 20 years later.
questions.explanation: The passage says 'His dream of twenty years before had saved his life'.

questions.text: The story tells us that _________.

choices.A: a dream may come true some time later
choices.B: a dream is always a dream
choices.C: people should not believe their dreams
choices.D: people should always believe their dreams

questions.explanation: The story shows that the man's dream came true and saved his life.

question_sets.context:
Have you ever heard your own voice? "Of course," you say.
Has anyone else ever heard your voice? Again you say, "Of course."
But that's not quite true. Nobody else has ever heard your voice―the way you hear it. When you talk, you set up sound waves(声波). The air outside your head carries the sound waves to your outer ears. But, of course, the sound of your voice begins inside your head. The bones(骨头) of your head_pick up_the sound waves, too. They carry the sound waves straight to your inner(里面的) ears. You get the sound from the outside and the inside too. Other people get just the sound waves from the outside. That's why they don't hear your voice the way you do.

questions.text: Sound travels in the form(形式) of __________.
questions.explanation: The passage mentions that sound travels in the form of sound waves.

questions.text: The sound of your voice begins ________.
questions.explanation: The passage mentions that the sound of your voice begins inside your head.

questions.text: When you talk, other people hear your voice _______.

choices.A: through the bones of your head

questions.explanation: The passage says other people only get sound waves from the outside.

questions.text: The phrase "pick up" here means ________.
questions.explanation: In this context, "pick up" means to receive or get.

questions.text: The passage is mainly about _________.

choices.B: the way you hear your own voice
choices.C: voice gets around far and wide
choices.D: the different ways you and others hear your voice

questions.explanation: The passage explains why you and others hear your voice differently.

question_sets.context:
An officer was talking to some new soldiers. He was going to train them for some time.
This was his first lesson. So he began, "My name is Stone, and I'm even harder than a stone, so you must do everything I tell you, or there'll be trouble. Don't try any tricks, and then you won't get into trouble."
Then he went to each soldier one after another and asked him his name.
"Speak loudly. You must let everyone hear you clearly." He said, "And don't forget to call me, sir."
Each soldier told him his own name until he came to the last one. This man kept quiet when the officer asked the same question. The officer shouted at him, "When I ask you a question, answer it at once! I'll ask you again: What's your name, soldier?"
The soldier looked sad, but at last he said, "My name is Stonebreaker, sir!"

questions.text: The officer began his first lesson by <blank>.
questions.explanation: The officer starts by saying "My name is Stone".

questions.text: "I'm even harder than a stone" means <blank>.

choices.A: he was as strong as a stone
choices.B: he was very strict with the soldiers
choices.C: It was difficult to attack him

questions.explanation: It means the officer wants to show the soldiers how strict he is.

questions.text: The officer wanted to make the soldiers <blank>.
questions.explanation: He warns them to do everything he asks.

questions.text: He told the soldiers <blank> when they were answering questions.
questions.explanation: He asks them to speak loudly so everyone can hear.

questions.text: The last soldier hesitated (犹豫) to tell the officer his name because <blank>.

choices.A: his name is something similar to the officer's
choices.B: he was so frightened by the officer that he couldn't say a word
choices.C: he was afraid that he would offend (冒犯) the officer

questions.explanation: His name is Stonebreaker, which is relevant to officer's name, Stone.

Beijing (Xinhua) ―― Chinese have started to enjoy cars at low prices after the country became a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO). At the same time, competition (竞争) between people has become stronger. According to China's Ministry of Personnel (人事部), About 170 million people will lose their jobs after the country has joined the WTO.
However, many Chinese people living in other countries have come back home to face the challenges (挑战). So far, about 130 thousand people have returned. These days, people, especially (尤其) youths, have got to know the challenges of entry into the WTO. Books on the WTO have been hot selling. Some people are learning more about the WTO by going to night schools.

question_sets.context:
E-mail systems at thousands of companies and government offices around the world were attacked by a virus (病毒) called "Melissa" that disguises itself as an "important message" from a friend.
Even though there was a weekend warning, more than 50,000 companies at about 100 places around the world have been attacked by the virus, computer experts said on Monday.
The virus began to show up last Friday and spread rapidly the next first workday by making computers send off dozens of e-mails containing (包含) the virus. Although the virus had no longlasting damage to a computer, its effects were far-reaching.
Michael Vaties, a senior US official said military (军事的) and government computers were damaged, along with thousands of the other institutions (机构) systems. The body of e-mail message says, "Here is what you ask for……." Once the user opens it, the virus digs into the user's address book and sends out messages to the first 50 addresses. The reason the virus spread so rapidly is that you're getting it from people you know and trust. So anyone who gets an unexpected e-mail with the "Important Message" subject line is advised not to open it and delete (删除) it immediately.

questions.text: From the passage we know that the virus attacked thousands of computers on <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage states that 'computer experts said on Monday'.

choices.A: it makes computers work without stop
choices.C: it sends out messages to dozens of computers at one time

questions.explanation: The passage mentions that the virus send out messages to the first 50 addresses.

questions.explanation: Disguise means to conceal the true nature of something.

choices.B: Thousands of computers were attacked by virus one by one.
choices.C: The "Important Message" carries an important message from a friend.

questions.explanation: The passage says military and government computers were damaged.

questions.explanation: The passage is about a virus and its rapid spread.

question_sets.context:
Henry liked drinking and spent all his money on it. So he stole(偷)some money from the shop . Mr. Hunt, the shopkeeper , was told about it and sent the young man away . Soon the people in the small town knew about it and he couldn't find any work there. He got into trouble. Sometimes he had no food and lived in the cold house .
One morning Henry got up at half past twelve. He tried to find something to eat, but he failed. He was walking in the street looking around. He hoped to try his luck in the crowd(人群). Suddenly(突然)he saw a lot of people standing at a corner of the building. He hurried there and found an old man was selling all kinds of nice teapots there. Henry found the old man always put the money into a red teapot after he had sold one. He pretended(假装)to choose the teapots and was going to steal the red one. When the old man was busy receiving two women , he took the red teapot away . But it had no bottom(底)and the money dropped onto the ground . He stood there and didn't know what to do.
"If you want a teapot , sir , " the old man said with a smile , "you'd better choose an intact(完好无缺)one!"

choices.D: meet some friends in the street

questions.explanation: Henry hoped to try his luck in the crowd, implying he wanted to steal.

questions.text: Henry was choosing among the teapots , in fact , he <blank>.

choices.B: was helping the old man watch them
choices.D: really wanted to buy one for himself

questions.explanation: Henry pretended to choose the teapots but was going to steal the red one.

questions.text: The old man was <blank>.
questions.explanation: The old man knew Henry's intention and cleverly pointed out that the teapot had no bottom.

question_sets.context: You might think the largest library in the world would be in Europe(欧洲)．But it isn't. It's in Washington D.C.. It's called the Library of Congress(国会)．President(总统) John Adams started the library in 1800 for members of Congress．He wanted them to be able to read books about law(法律)．The first 740 books were bought in England．They were set up in the room where Congress met．Then Thomas Jefferson sold Congress many of his own books．He felt Congress should have books on all subjects not just on law. This idea changed the library for good．The library grew and grew. Now it covers(覆盖) acres( 英亩) of land.There are 20 million books and many pictures, movies, and machines.Many different kinds of Experts(专家)work there．Hundreds of people call every day with all kinds of questions. Many of them get answers right over the phone．

question_sets.context:
The date was like any other day in his life. After school Bill walked past the shop on the street corner. he stopped to look at the front row of shoes, and he felt sorry for himself. He really wanted to have a pair for his birthday.
He sadly walked away and thought of what to tell his mother. He knew she would give him anything if she could. But he also knew very well she had little money. He decided not to go home at once, as he looked worried and he didn't want to make his mother worry about it. So he went to the park and there he sat on the grass. Then he saw a girl in a wheel chair(轮椅). He found that the girl moved the wheels with her hands. Bill looked at her carefully and was surprised to see that the girl had no feet. He looked down at his own feet. "It is much better to be without shoes than without feet," he thought. It was not right for him to feel so sorry and sad. He went away and smiled, thinking he was more lucky in life.

choices.B: Bill's mother was a kind-hearted woman.

choices.D: Bill's mother often bought presents for Bill's birthday.

choices.D: Because he didn't want to give his mother any trouble.

questions.explanation: The passage states that Bill didn't go home at once because he looked worried and didn't want to make his mother worry.

choices.D: didn't know what to do with his shoes

questions.explanation: After seeing the girl in the wheelchair, Bill realized he was lucky to have feet and thought he was more lucky in life.

question_sets.context:
Tom arrived at the bus station quite early for Paris bus. The bus for Paris would not leave until five to twelve. He saw a lot of people waiting in the station. Some were standing in line(排队), others were walking around. There was a group of schoolgirls. Their teacher was trying to keep them in line. Tom looked around but there was no place for him to sit.
He walked into the station cafe(咖啡馆). He looked up at the clock there. It was only twenty to twelve. He found a seat and sat down before a large mirror(镜子) on the wall. Just then, Mike, one of Tom's workmates came in and sat with Tom.
"What time is your bus?" asked Mike.
"There's plenty of time yet," answered Tom.
"Well, I'll get you some more tea then," said Mike.
They talked while drinking. Then Tom looked at the clock again. "Oh! It's going backward (倒行)!" He cried. "A few minutes ago it was twenty to twelve and now it's half past eleven."
"You're looking at the clock in the mirror." said Mike. Tom was so sad. The next bus was not to leave for another hour. Since then Tom has never liked mirrors.

questions.text: Tom went into the station cafe because <blank>.

choices.A: Mike asked him to have a cup of tea
choices.B: it was quite early and he could find a seat there
choices.C: he didn't like to stay with the schoolgirls
choices.D: he wanted to have a drink with his workmate there

questions.explanation: From the passage, Tom went to the cafe because he arrived early and wanted to find a seat.

questions.text: What time was it in fact when Tom looked at the clock in the mirror?
questions.explanation: Tom saw half past eleven in the mirror, meaning it was actually twenty to twelve plus 30 minutes, which is half past twelve.
questions.test_point: Reading Comprehension; Inference Skills; Attention to Detail

questions.text: From the story we know that when we look at a clock in a mirror, we will find <blank>.
questions.explanation: The passage explains that the clock appears to be going backward when viewed in a mirror.

questions.text: Which of the following is true?

choices.A: Tom arrived in Paris on time
choices.B: The next bus would leave in half an hour
choices.C: After that Tom didn't like clocks any longer
choices.D: Tom looked at the clock in the mirror only once

questions.explanation: The passage states Tom didn't like mirrors since then, meaning option D is true.
questions.test_point: Reading Comprehension; Inference Skills; Attention to Detail

questions.text: Which of the following is the title(题目) of the story?
questions.explanation: The story revolves around the incident with the clock in the mirror, making it the most appropriate title.

question_sets.context:
Nov. 10, 1998
Francis,
Hello!How are you? It was good to hear from you. Have the flood waters gone down?
The hurricanes (the big winds) have not hit us very hard. We did not have school one day because we thought Hurricane George was going to hit us, but it only rained. We also got rain from Hurricane Mitch. Now the weather is mostly in the 70s (Fahrenheit). It stays warm in Florida all year long.
I just got back from visiting my sister in Tennessee. I applied for teaching jobs up there because I'd really like to move up there after I graduate in May.
I hope this letter finds you healthy and happy.
Mandy Hamilton

question_sets.context:
When Mr. David retired(退休), he bought a small house in a village near the sea. He liked it and hoped to live a quiet life in it.
But to his great surprise, many tourists came to see his house in summer holidays, for it was the most interesting building in the village. From morning to night there were tourists outside the house. They kept looking into the rooms through the windows and many of them even went into Mr. David's garden. This was too much for Mr. David. He decided to drive the visitors away. So he put a notice on the window. The notice said: "If you want to satisfy your curiosity(好奇心), came in and look round. Price: twenty dollars." Mr. David was sure that the visitors would stop coming, but he was wrong. More and more visitors came and Mr. David had to spend every day showing them around his house. "I came here to retire, not to work as a guide." he said angrily. In the end, he sold the house and moved away.

questions.explanation: The passage states the house was the most interesting building in the village.

choices.D: to get some money out of the visitors

question_sets.context:
We each have a memory(记忆力). That's why we can still remember things after a long time. Some people have very good memories and they can easily learn many things by heart, but some people can only remember things when they say or do them again and again. Many of the great men of the world have got surprising memories.
A good memory is a great help in learning a language. Everybody learns his mother language when he is a small child. He hears the sounds, remembers them and then he learns to speak. Some children are living with their parents in foreign countries. They can learn two languages as easily as one because they hear, remember and speak two languages every day. In school it is not so easy to learn a foreign language because the pupils have so little time for it, and they are busy with other subjects, too.
But your memory will become better and better when you do more and more exercises.

question_sets.context:
Of all the stars the sun is the nearest to the earth. Millions of other stars are even bigger and brighter than the sun. They look small only because they are much farther away. You can't see them in the daytime. But if you go out at night, you'll be able to see thousands of them.
The earth is one of the sun's planets, and the moon is our nearest neighbour in space, and men have visited it already. No man has travelled farther than the moon, but spaceships without people have reached other planets.
Many countries have sent up man-made satellites to circle the earth. With their help, people have done much research in many fields of science.
Our country sometimes uses man-made satellites to send and receive TV programmes. This has helped the people of China and other countries to understand each other better.

question_sets.context:
Once Effendi had a joke with the Prime Minister (宰相). He said that the Minister would die the next day. The next day, the Minister fell to the ground from the horse and really died. When the king learned this, he got angry and sent his men to catch Effendi at once. "
When Effendi was brought to him, the king shouted angrily, "Effendi, since (既然) you knew when my Minister would die, you must know the date of your own death (死) . Say it out, or you'll die today." "
Effendi looked at the king for a while. Then he answered, "But how can I know? I'll die two days earlier than you." The king was afraid that if he killed Effendi, he himself would die after that. He thought he must keep Effendi alive (活着) as long as possible, so he let Effendi go.

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that the minister fell off the horse and died.

choices.A: Because the king wanted to know when he himself would die.
choices.B: Because the wanted to find an excuse to kill Effendi.

choices.D: Because he wanted to know when Effendi would die.

question_sets.context:
One day Archie, the clown( 小丑 )went into a shop to buy a new pair of shoes.
"Good morning, sir." said the salesman. "What can I do for you?"
Archie told him, " A new pair of shoes, please." He said. "Brown" ,he added.
"Of course , sir," said the salesman. "Right away." And he went off to find some suitable shoes, which were piled( 堆 )so high that he couldn't see where to take.
"Try these, sir." said the salesman.
Archie tried four pairs of shoes, but he said they were too big or too small, or like boats or like pincers. None of them satisfied(使….满意 ) him.
"Oh dear," said the salesman. "I can't find a pair to fit you at all."
"Let me have a look," said Archie, hunting among the shoes scattered on the floor.
"Here we are," he said, "Look, these fit me properly."
"But you can't have those, sir!" cried the salesman excitedly.
"Why not?" said Archie loudly.
"Because they happen to be the boxes I keep the shoes in."

questions.explanation: The story focuses on finding a shoe that fits the clown properly, implying that the clown requires a more specialized fit due to his profession.
questions.test_point: Reading Comprehension; Inference Skills; Implicit Information

choices.D: were the most suitable to his feet

question_sets.context:
Maxie Anderson and his 23-year-old son Kris flew from California to Quebec. It was a 3100-mile trip, and it took 100 hours. But this was no ordinary flight. There was not even a plane. The pilot( 飞行员 ) and copilot were in a balloon (气球 ).
Maxie and Kris wanted to make the first nonstop balloon trip across North America. They started in San Francisco, California and hoped to land in Kitty Hank, North Carolina. But the Adersons had some bad luck. Strong winds blew them 1,100 miles north, and they landed near the forest of Quebec. There were other problems on the trip too. While they were flying over the Rock Mountains it was cold. There was also little air, so they needed to take oxygen (氧气).
After the trip, Kris said he did not want any more adventures (冒险 ). "Man always has a dream. I'm sure I'll think of something else to try."

question_sets.context:
Just as the teacher was coming into the classroom, one of the boys, Bill, said loudly, "The teacher is a real fool."
To their surprise, the teacher pretended(假装 )not to have heard this. He paid no attention to anyone and said nothing. He just went up to the teacher's desk and began the class. He said, "Today we are going to study punctuation(标点). Punctuation in sentences is very important. Look at the sentence, please, boys and girls."
He picked up a piece of chalk and wrote the following sentence on the blackboard: Bill says the teacher is a real fool.
The class laughed at once.
"Now," the teacher went on, "with two commas I can change the meaning of the sentence and it reads: Bill, says the teacher, is a real fool."

question_sets.context:
The date was like any other day in his life. After school Bill walked past the shop on the street corner. he stopped to look at the front row of shoes, and he felt sorry for himself.
He sadly walked away and thought of what to tell his mother. He knew she would give him anything if she could. But he also knew very well she had little money. He decided not to go home at once, as he looked worried and he didn't want to make his mother worry about it. So he went to the park and there he sat on the grass. Then he saw a girl in a wheel chair(轮椅). He found that the girl moved the wheels with her hands. Bill looked at her carefully and was surprised to see that the girl had no feet. He looked down at his own feet. "It is much better to be without shoes than without feet," he thought. It was not right for him to feel so sorry and sad. He went away and smiled, thinking he was more lucky in life.

questions.text: Bill was sorry that <blank>.

choices.A: the shoes in the shop were not the right size for him
choices.B: he forgot to bring any money with him
choices.D: he walked past the shoe shop

questions.explanation: Bill felt sorry for himself when he stopped to look at the shoes, because he wanted a pair for his birthday but knew his mother couldn't afford them.

questions.text: Which of the following is right?

choices.B: Bill's mother was a kind-hearted woman.
choices.C: Bill's mother wouldn't buy him anything.
choices.D: Bill's mother often bought presents for Bill's birthday.

questions.explanation: The passage says Bill knew his mother would give him anything if she could, implying she was kind-hearted.

questions.text: Why didn't Bill go home at once?

choices.A: Because his mother was at work.
choices.B: Because his mother wouldn't give him any money.
choices.C: Because he wanted to sit on the grass in the park.
choices.D: Because he didn't want to give his mother any trouble.

questions.explanation: Bill didn't go home at once because he looked worried and didn't want to make his mother worry about it.

questions.text: In the park, Bill found a girl <blank>.
questions.explanation: Bill saw a girl in a wheelchair who had no feet.

questions.text: At last Bill <blank>.

choices.A: decided to buy a new pair of shoes
choices.C: thought he was more lucky in life than the girl in the wheel chair
choices.D: didn't know what to do with his shoes

questions.explanation: Bill realized it was better to be without shoes than without feet and thought he was more lucky in life.

question_sets.context:
Teeth are important. Strong , healthy teeth help you chew foods that help you grow. They help you speak chearly. And , they help you look your best. Here are sometipsfor you to take care of your teeth.
1.Brush your teeth the right way.
Brush your teeth at least twice a day――after breakfast and before bedtime. If you can, brush after lunch or after sweet snacks , too.
Brush all of your teeth , not just the front ones. Spend time brushing teeth along the sides and back of your mouth. Brush away from your gums , too.
Spend at least three minutes each time you brush. Play a song you like to help pass the time. Get a new toothbrush every three months. When you buy your toothbrush , be sure it has soft *bristles.
2.Learn how to *floss your teeth
Flossing is a very important way to keep your teeth healthy. Food may hide in places where a toothbrush cannot get to , like the space between two teeth. Flossing can help get rid of it. Carefully move the floss between two teeth , up and down. You'll need to floss your teeth at least once a day.
3.Have good eating habits.
You need to be careful about what you eat and drink. Eating sugar is a major cause of tooth *decay. Eating sugar before you go to bed can make things even worse. Eat lots of fruit and vegetables and drink water instead of soda.

questions.text: The passage is mainly about_________.

choices.A: how to take care of your teeth
choices.D: how to form good eating habits

questions.explanation: The passage introduces how to brush your teeth, floss your teeth, and have good eating habits, which are all about how to take care of your teeth.

questions.text: The word"tip"in this passage means <blank>

choices.A: money given to the waiter for personal services
choices.B: piece of advice on how to do something

questions.explanation: The sentence says 'Here are some tips for you to take care of your teeth'. Thus, 'tip' means 'piece of advice on how to do something'.

questions.text: When you brush your teeth , at least <blank> minute(s) is necessary.
questions.explanation: Spend at least three minutes each time you brush.

questions.text: Which is Not mentioned in this passage ?
questions.explanation: The passage introduces how to brush your teeth, floss your teeth, and have good eating habits, but does not mention 'Going to see the dentist'.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is NOT true according to this article ?

choices.A: We should brush our teeth at least twice a day.
choices.B: Flossing can help to get rid of the food hidden between two teeth.
choices.C: One of the major causes of tooth decay is eating sugar.
choices.D: We don't have to brush our teeth if we eat a lot of fruit and vegetables.

questions.explanation: We should brush our teeth even if we eat a lot of fruit and vegetables.

question_sets.context:
"We're going to move," Jimmy said to Mr. James, his teacher, with tears in his eyes. "Dad lost his job and now we don't have enough money to live in our house."
Pam was walking by and just heard Jimmy's talk with Mr. James.
In the lunchroom, Pam met Carol and said, " I've got something to tell you about Jimmy." As she started to tell Carol about Jimmy's dad, several other classmates stopped to listen. Pam felt bad telling what she had heard but she went on anyway.
After school, Pam saw some of her classmates talking to Jimmy. "Where does your dad work?" One of the boys asked. Jimmy's face turned red. He left without answering.
Pam felt terrible, because she didn't mean to hurt Jimmy. And she hadn't thought that some of the classmates
would make jokes and laugh at Jimmy about his father's losing his job. Pam didn't know what she could do to help Jimmy.

questions.text: The story wants to tell us <blank>

choices.B: girls don't like to talk to boys.
choices.C: students like to report to the teacher.

questions.explanation: The story is about Pam told Jimmy's secret to her classmates, and her classmates made jokes and laugh at Jimmy about his father's losing his job. Thus, the story wants to tell us secrets are hard to keep.

questions.text: Jimmy's family had to move because <blank>.

choices.B: they had a better place to live in.
choices.C: his classmates were not kind enough.

questions.explanation: "Dad lost his job and now we don't have enough money to live in our house."

questions.text: Jimmy's face turning red shows that he didn't <blank>.

choices.C: want to talk about his father.

questions.explanation: Jimmy's face turned red shows that he is embarrassed and doesn't want to talk about his father.

questions.text: Pam felt sorry <blank>.

choices.A: and wanted to do something for Jimmy.
choices.B: but went on laughing at Jimmy.
choices.C: so she stopped to listen to others.

questions.explanation: Pam felt terrible, because she didn't mean to hurt Jimmy. Pam didn't know what she could do to help Jimmy.

questions.text: The whole story happened <blank>.
questions.explanation: The story happened in the lunchroom and after school.

question_sets.context:
Have you ever seen a horse with toes(脚趾)? Millions of years ago, horses had many toes. They had four toes on each front foot. They had three toes on each back foot. The horses were smaller than cats.
These small horses lived in the forest. Their many toes helped the horses run over the soft wet ground.
It was very hot in the forest. But the weather changed. It became cold. Many trees couldn't live in cold weather. The trees died and fell. Open field took the place of(代替) forests. The sun made the ground dry and hard(坚硬).
Horses began to change too.They began to get bigger.This took a long time. On the dry hard land, horses needed only their middle toes for running. Their middle toes became hard. After a long time horses had only one hard toe on each foot. We call this hard toe a hoof(马蹄).

questions.text: Long ago, the horse had four toes on each of its <blank>.
questions.explanation: The text states, 'They had four toes on each front foot.'

questions.text: The cats were <blank> the horses at that time.
questions.explanation: The text says, 'The horses were smaller than cats,' implying cats were bigger.

questions.text: Which of the three sentences is true?

choices.A: The weather stays the same the whole year all over the world.
choices.B: When the weather changed, animals began to change too.
choices.C: Cats were bigger in the past than they are today.

questions.explanation: The text mentions that 'Horses began to change too' after the weather changed.

questions.text: On the dry hard land <blank>.

choices.A: horses needed a lot of room for running
choices.B: a horse needed more than four toes for running
choices.C: horses needed only their middle toes for running

questions.explanation: The text says, 'On the dry hard land, horses needed only their middle toes for running.'

questions.text: Now each horse has <blank> on its feet.
questions.explanation: The text says that after a long time horses had only one hard toe on each foot

question_sets.context:
A friend of mine named Paul received an expensive car from his brother as a Christmas present. On Christmas Eve when Paul came out of his office a street urchin(顽童) was walking around a shining car."Is this your car, Paul?"he asked.
Paul answered,"Yes, my brother gave it to me for Christmas."The boy was surprised."You mean your brother gave it to you and it didn't cost you anything. Boy. I wish…"He hesitated(犹豫).
Of course Paul knew what he was going to wish for. He was going to wish he had a brother like that. But what the boy said surprised Paul greatly.
"I wish,"the boy went on,"that I could be a brother like that."Paul looked at the boy in surprise, then he said again,"Would you like to take a ride in my car?"
"Oh, yes, I'd love that."
After a short ride, the boy turned and with his eyes shining, said:"Paul, would you mind driving in front of my house?"
Paul smiled a little. He thought he knew what the boy wanted. He wanted to show his neighbours that he could ride home in a big car. But Paul was wrong again,"Will you stop where those two steps are?"the boy asked.
He ran up to the steps. Then in a short while Paul heard him coming back, but he was not coming fast. He was carrying his little crippled(残疾) brother. He sat him down on the step and pointed to the car.
"There she is. Buddy, just like I told you upstairs. His brother gave it to him for Christmas and it didn't cost him a cent. And some day I'm going to give you one just like it...then you can see for yourself all nice things in the Christmas window that I've been trying to tell you about."
Paul got out and lifted the boy to the front seat of his car. The shining-eyed older brother climbed in beside him and the three of them began an unforgettable holiday ride.

questions.text: The street urchin was very surprised when <blank>.

choices.B: Paul told him about the car
choices.D: he was walking around the car

questions.explanation: The urchin was surprised when Paul told him it was a Christmas gift.

questions.text: From the story we can see the urchin <blank>.

choices.A: wished to give his brother a car
choices.B: wanted Paul's brother to give him a car
choices.C: wished he could have a brother like Paul's
choices.D: wished Paul could be a brother like that

questions.explanation: The urchin wished he could give his brother a car.

questions.text: The urchin asked Paul to stop his car in front of his house <blank>.

choices.A: to show his neighbours the big car
choices.B: to show he had a rich friend
choices.C: to let his brother about his wish
choices.D: to show his crippled brother the car

questions.explanation: The urchin wanted to show his disabled brother the car and the Christmas window.

questions.text: We can infer(推断) from the story that <blank>.

choices.B: the urchin had a deep love for his brother
choices.C: the urchin wished to have a rich brother
choices.D: the urchin's wish came true in the end

questions.explanation: The urchin's actions demonstrate deep love for his brother.

questions.text: The best name of the story is <blank>.
questions.explanation: This title encapsulates the core theme of fraternal love, emphasizing the act of Paul offering a holiday ride and brotherly love.

question_sets.context:
Many Chinese people have a good time during the Chinese New Year. It usually comes in February. Each year gets a name. It may be called the Year of the Dog or the Year of the Monkey instead of 1970 or 1980.
Usually there is dragon dance in the street. The dragon is a strange animal about twenty feet long. It's made of paper and cloth. Men hide under the dragon and make a lot of noise by shouting. There are always plenty of fireworks.
After the dragon dance, the children sing and dance in the street.

questions.text: The Chinese New Year usually comes in ________.
questions.explanation: From the first sentence, we know that the Chinese New Year usually comes in February.

questions.text: The Chinese people may call 1992______.
questions.explanation: In the first paragraph, it's mentioned that each year gets a name, and it can be the Year of the Dog, the Year of the Monkey... Though the passage doesn't directly tell what the year of 1992 is, it's reasonable to infer that it can be called "the Year of Dragon".

questions.text: The dragon was made of ________.
questions.explanation: The dragon is made of paper and cloth.

questions.text: The dragon dance needs a lot of _________.
questions.explanation: Men hide under the dragon and make a lot of noise by shouting.

questions.text: After the dragon dance, the children ________.
questions.explanation: After the dragon dance, the children sing and dance in the street.

question_sets.context: Basketball is one sport ―perhaps the only sport―whose exact origin(确切的起源)can safely be told. During the winter of 1891 ―1892, Dr James Naismith, a college instructor(大学讲师)in Springfield, Massachusetts, invented the game of basketball in order to provide(提供)exercise for the students between the closing of the football season and the opening of the baseball season. He attached(系)fruit baskets overhead on the walls at opposite ends of the gymnasium(体育馆), and, using a soccer ball, organized(组织)nine―man teams to play his new game. In this new game the purpose(目的)was to toss (投)the ball into one basket and try to keep the opposting team from tossing the ball into the other basket. Although there have been many changes in the rules(such as the reduction of the number of players on a team from nine to five), the game is basically(基本地)the same today. The United States soldiers took it to the Philippines in 1900 and to Europe during World War I, and, being adopted(被采用)by foreign countries it soon became a world―wide sport. It is interesting that although basketball was made as an indoor game, in other countries it is now played almost entirely(完全地)outdoors.

questions.text: Basketball was started _________.

choices.D: in a place not mentioned(被提到)

questions.explanation: During the winter of 1891 ―1892, Dr James Naismith, a college instructor(大学讲师)in Springfield, Massachusetts, invented the game of basketball.

questions.text: Original(起初的) basketball was played by ________.
questions.explanation: Nine-man teams to play his new game.

questions.text: Basketball is mainly played indoors _______ according to(按照)the passage.
questions.explanation: In other countries it is now played almost entirely(完全地)outdoors.

questions.text: What does writer say is particularly unusual(尤其不平常)about basketball as compared with(与……比较)other sports?

choices.A: It was invented for college students but became popular only after it was adopted by soldiers.
choices.B: It began as an indoor game but later became equally(平等地)common as on outdoor game.
choices.C: We know exactly when, where, and by whom it was invented.
choices.D: We know exactly when it was first played outside of the country of its origin.

questions.explanation: Basketball is one sport whose exact origin can safely be told.

questions.text: What connection(联系)does the writer mention between the game of basketball and the game of soccer?

choices.A: Basketball was made to provide exercise for students before the beginning of the soccer season.
choices.B: Basketball was invented by a well-known soccer player.
choices.C: Basketball has replaced (代替)soccer as the most popular sport in some countries.
choices.D: Basketball was first played with a soccer.

questions.explanation: Using a soccer ball, organized nine―man teams to play his new game.

question_sets.context:
Here is an examination notice Mrs. Dickson gave to her students last week. Read it and answer the questions.
To the students of Class 3A
1.Examinations start on June 22 and end on June 23.
2.The time for each of the subject is:
English June 22 9:30 A.M.－ 10:30 A.M.
Math June 22 11:00 A.M.－ 12:00 P.M.
History June 22 2:30 P.M.－ 3:30 P.M.
PE June 23 8:00 A.M. － 10:00 A.M.
Music June 23 1:00 P.M. － 3:00 P.M.
3.For the PE test(测试), go to the gym.．For the music test, go to the Piano Room. All else are written tests. They will be held in classroom 3A.

question_sets.context:
Once there was an old farmer with a horse. The horse was almost as old as himself. He set out(出发) in the morning with his young son to sell the horse before it died.
Father and son walked, because the farmer did not want the horse to be too tired. They met two men on the road. The two men said, "Why are you walking, farmer? You have a horse. It is a long way to the market." The farmer knew that this was true. So he rode on the horse, while his son walked.
Then they met two ladies. They said: "What are you doing up there, farmer? Can't you see how tired your boy is?" So the farmer got down, and his son rode instead.
Next, three old men stopped them. One of them said: "Why are you walking, farmer? Get up. It's too hot for an old man like you to walk today." So the farmer got up behind his son, and rode on. Some time later, a young woman passed them. "Why aren't you walking?" She said, "It isn't far to the market. Give your poor old horse a rest."
So the farmer and his son got down once again.��
It is a fact that you can't please(讨好) all the people all the time.

questions.text: The farmer was <blank>.

choices.A: very old, and his horse was almost as old as himself.
choices.B: almost always older than his horse
choices.C: a little older than his horse

questions.explanation: According to the passage, "The horse was almost as old as himself."

questions.text: The two men on the road <blank>.

choices.A: asked how far it was to the market
choices.B: asked why the farmer was not riding on his horse
choices.C: said that they thought the horse looked very tired

questions.explanation: The two men asked why the farmer was walking when he had a horse.

questions.text: The two ladies said it was wrong for <blank>.

choices.A: the farmer to ride such a tired horse
choices.B: the boy to ride instead of his father
choices.C: the farmer to ride while his son walked

questions.explanation: The two ladies pointed out that the farmer should not be riding while his son was walking because the boy looked tired.

question_sets.context:
Tom is a little boy, and he is only seven years old. One day he went to the cinema. It was the first time to do that. He bought a ticket and then went in. But after two or three minutes he came out, bought a second ticket and went in again. After a few minutes he came out again and bought a third ticket. Two or three minutes later he came out and asked for another ticket.
Then the girl in the ticket office asked him, "why do you buy so many tickets? How many friends do you meet?"
Tom answered, "No, I have no friend here. But a big boy always stops me at the door and tears my ticket to pieces."

questions.text: Tom wanted to buy <blank> when the girl asked him.
questions.explanation: He asked for another ticket after buying the third one.

choices.A: it was the big boy's job
choices.B: the big boy didn't like Tom
choices.C: the big boy didn't know Tom
choices.D: Tom didn't buy ticket at all.

questions.explanation: The big boy tore the ticket to pieces, which is a job.

questions.text: From the story we know <blank>

choices.A: the little boy had a lot of money
choices.B: B. the little boy knew nothing about the cinema
choices.C: the big boy wasn't friendly to Tom
choices.D: the girl wanted to get more money

questions.explanation: Tom bought a ticket and then went in. But after two or three minutes he came out, bought a second ticket and went in again. It means Tom knew nothing about the cinema.

questions.text: Which of the following is Not true in the passage?

choices.A: Tom bought the tickets for himself
choices.B: Tom didn't go to the cinema before
choices.C: Tom was too young to make friends
choices.D: Tom had no friend at the cinema.

questions.explanation: We cannot deduce that Tom was too young to make friends. It only mentions that it was the first time he went to the cinema.

question_sets.context:
What's the meaning of "dark horse"? It's someone who wins when no one expects it.
Han Xiaopeng took China's first gold on snow. He became an Olympic "dark horse" last Thursday by winning the gold medal in men's freestyle aerial skiing(自由式滑雪空中技巧) at Turin in Italy. He made two almost perfect jumps for the highest score. Han had never won a world gold medal before, let alone(更不用说) in the Olympics!
"I never thought this would happen," said the 23-year-old. "I feel like I'm in a dream." It's China's second gold medal at the Turin Olympics. But more important, Han's gold was the country's first ever in a snow sport. In 2002, China's Yang Yang won the gold for speed skating at the winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, US.
Just because Han's win was unexpected doesn't mean that he didn't work hard.
Han grew up in Jiangsu Province. Before he started his training on snow, he used to be an acrobat(杂技演员) at a circus. In 1995, a coach found his talent(才能). The coach, Yang Er'qi, said Han had the agility(灵活性) and courage to be a ski jumper. When Yang first took the 12-year-old to northern China, the boy couldn't swim, skate or ski. But he wasn't afraid of the high platform(跳台) and kept on training.
Han almost left the sport after hurting his knee months before the Salt Lake Games. In that Olympics he only got 24th. "I was hopeless at that time, but my family and the coach stood firmly(坚强地) behind me, helping me through," he recalled.
Han Xiaopeng worked so hard that he won the gold medal in the Olympics at last. Because of his success, more and more people in China are becoming interested in skiing. We are proud of him and we hope he will have another big success in the next winter Olympics.

questions.text: What does 'dark horse' mean? It means _____________.

choices.B: someone who is expected to win
choices.C: a horse which likes living in the dark

questions.explanation: The first sentence of the passage defines 'dark horse' as 'someone who wins when no one expects it'.

questions.text: Where did Han Xiaopeng take China's first gold on snow?
questions.explanation: The passage states that he won the gold medal in Turin, Italy.

questions.text: What made the coach, Yang Er'qi, choose Han Xiaopeng to be a ski jumper?

choices.A: He had the agility and wasn't afraid of the high platform.
choices.B: He was good at skiing though he was only 12 years old.
choices.C: He was born in the north of China and liked sports on snow.
choices.D: He had the talent and he had won a world gold medal before.

questions.explanation: The passage mentions that the coach said Han had the agility and courage to be a ski jumper and he wasn't afraid of the high platform.

questions.text: Which of the following sentences isNOT TRUEaccording to the passage?

choices.A: He was 23 when he won the gold medal at the winter Olympics.
choices.B: He made two almost perfect jumps and got the highest score.
choices.C: No one had won the gold before Han Xiaopeng at the winter Olympics.
choices.D: He never gave up even though he had faced many difficulties.

questions.explanation: The passage stated that in 2002, China's Yang Yang won the gold for speed skating at the winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, US.

questions.text: What is the best title for this passage?

choices.A: A Dark Horse at the Winter Olympics

questions.explanation: The passage is mainly about Han Xiaopeng becoming a dark horse at the Winter Olympics.

question_sets.context:
Karnishakuji 4-16 2
Tokyo 145
October 24,1999
Concord School of English
23 Essex St.
Concord NH 03301

Dear Madam or Sir:
One of the teachers at my school in Japan told me that your school has summer courses. I am planning to go to the United States next summer and would like to take a short one-month course.
I am 18 years old and have been studying English for six years. I am going to study English at the university. I have ever been to a few countries, such as China, England, Korea, but never to the U.S, and I think a trip will help me improve my English.
Could you send me a catalogue (目录) and application from (申请表)?I would also like information about New Hampshire and other places nearby.
I hope to do some traveling when the course is over.
Thank you in advance (提前) . I look forward to you reply.
Very truly yours,
Mariko Kobori

questions.explanation: Mariko is 18 and has been studying English for 6 years, so he started at age 12 (18-6=12).

choices.A: ask to take the next summer English course

choices.C: get some advice on how to learn English

questions.explanation: Mariko states in the letter that she is planning to go to the United States next summer and would like to take a short one-month course.

question_sets.context:
Who will follow Yao Ming and became the next Chinese person to play in the NBA? Time Magazine says Yi Jianlian, a 2.1-metre tall teenager from Shenzhen, Guangdong Province, might be the one.
Fifteen-year old Yi is a good player and has the right size. He moves quickly. He plays for Guangdong Tigers Club team. He played in the Chinese Basketball Association―the CBA(中国篮球协会) last season and was the group's new player of the year. Yi could be a key player at the 2008 Beijing Olympics.
" It's my dream to play in the Olympics," Yi said. "It would be a great honour to play in the Olympics for the country, I hope I will get a chance."
Yi was 12 when he first picked up a basketball. At first his parents were against his playing basketball in a sports school. But they were changed by the fact that Yi has everything for a good player such as speed and size. Yi's basketball life almost ended before it began. When he first went to training, he almost gave up halfway through.
"I wanted to give up," Yi said. "I had never lived away from home before." But he decided to make the best of a difficult situation(处境).
His goal is to join Yao in the NBA. " We all look up to him, and I hope I can one day in the NBA, too," said Yi. "I need to learn and practice and stay_cool_before fame(名声)."

question_sets.context:
Never let the soil in your garden dry out. If it doesn't rain for a few days and the soil feels dry, water your garden. Be sure the water gets all the way down to the roots (the parts that grow down into the soil) of the plants, but don't water too much . You could drown your plants!
You may see some plants in your garden that you didn't put there. These are weeds(杂草).
Pull them out when the ground is soft and wet. Be sure you get out the roots, or the weeds will grow back.
Tall plants such as tomatoes need sticks to hold them up. Without sticks ,they'll fall over.
When your tomato plants get to be about two feet tall, it's time to stick to them. Push a long stick into the ground next to each plant. Tie the plant to the stick with string. As each plant grows taller, you'll have to tie it up again.
If you've planted seeds(种子), you can expect too many plants to come out.You have to clear some away, so that the plants left will have room to grow. This is called_thinning_.
If you've planted lettuce(莴苣)seeds, wait until the baby plants are about 1.5 inches tall.Then pull some of the plants out so that you leave about 8 inches between plants.
Now that you've done all the work to make a vegetable garden, it's time to enjoy what you've finished. Pick a red, ripe , juicy tomato. Eat it while it's still warm from the sun. Or cut it up and put it in a salad(沙拉)―made with lettuce you picked yourself, If you have more vegetables from your garden than you and your family can eat, give them to friends and neighbors. It's fun to have the joy you get from your garden together with others.

questions.text: What is the main idea of Paragraph ?

choices.A: Keep the soil in the garden a little wet.
choices.C: Water plants in the garden every day.

questions.explanation: The main idea of the paragraph is about keeping the soil in the garden from drying out.

choices.D: They like to grow next to each other

questions.explanation: The text mentions that tomatoes need sticks to hold them up because without sticks, they'll fall over.

choices.C: How to make a salad with lettuce
choices.D: What to do with the vegetables in the garden

questions.explanation: The writer emphasizes the joy of harvesting and sharing the vegetables, indicating that enjoying the result is the main point.

question_sets.context:
Every summer many people, girls and women as well as(还有) boys and men, try to swim from England to France or from France to England. The distance(距离) at the nearest points(点) is only about 20 miles but because of the strong tides(浪) the distance that must be swum is usually more than twice as far.
The first man who succeeded(成功) in swimming the English Channel(海峡) was Captain Wed, an Englishman. This was in August 1857. He landed in France 21 hours later after he jumped into the water at Dover. Since then there have been many successful swimmers and time has been shortened(缩短). In 1960 a Canadian crossed in 10 hours and 23 minutes. Because the sea is usually cold, swimmers cover their bodies with grease(油脂). This helps them to keep out the cold. They can also eat something, because some men go with them in small boats.

questions.explanation: He jumped into the water at Dover, so Dover may be a harbor.

questions.explanation: Only good swimmers can swim the Channel successfully.

question_sets.context:
Popular music in America is what every student likes. Students carry small radios with earphones and listen to music before class, after class, and at lunch. Students with cars buy large speakers and play the music loudly as they drive on the street.
Adult(成年的) drivers listen to music on the car radio as they drive to work. They also listen to the news about sports, the weather, and the life of American people. Most of the radio programmes are music.
Pop or popular music singers make much money. They make a CD or tape which radio stations use in many places. Once the popular singer is heard all over the country, young people buy his or her tape. Some of the money from these tapes comes to the singer. Wherever the singer goes, all the young people want to meet him or her. Now the singer has become a national star.
There are other kinds of music that are important to Americans. One is called folk(民间) music. It tells stories about the common(普通) life of Americans. Another is called western or country music. This was started by cowboys who would sing at night to the cows they were watching. Today, any music about country life and the love between a country boy and his girl is called western or country music.

questions.text: <blank> kinds of music are mentioned(提到) in this passage.
questions.explanation: Four kinds of music are mentioned: Popular music, Folk music, Western music, Country music.

choices.D: are wanted to sing on the radio

choices.D: Everyone in America wants to meet pop singers wherever they go

questions.explanation: Popular music in America is what every student likes.

question_sets.context:
We spent a day in the country and picked a lot of flowers. Our car was full of flowers inside! On the way home we had to stop at the traffic lights, and there my wife saw the bookshelf.
It stood outside a furniture(家具) shop. "Buy it," she said at once, "We'll carry it home on the roof-race(车顶架). I've always wanted one like that."
What could I do? Ten minutes later I was twenty dollars poorer, and the bookshelf was tied on to the roof-rack. It was tall and narrow(狭窄), quite heavy too.
As it was getting darker, I drove slowly. Other drivers seemed more polite than usual that evening. The police even stopped traffic to let us go through. Carrying furniture was a good idea.
After a time my wife said, "There's a long line of cars behind. Why don't they overtake(超车)?"
Just at that time a police car did overtake. The two officers inside looked at us seriously when they went past. But then, with a kind smile they asked us to follow their car through the busy traffic. The police car stopped at our village church(教堂). One of the officers came to me.
"Right, sir," he said. "Do you need anymore help now?"
I didn't quite understand. "Thanks, officer," I said. "You've been very kind. I live just down the road."
He was looking at our things: first at the flowers, then at the bookshelf. "Well, well," he said and laughed. "It's a bookshelf you've got there! We thought it was…er, something else."
My wife began to laugh. Suddenly I understood why the police drove here. I smiled at the officer, "yes, it's a bookshelf, but thanks again." I drove home as fast as I could.

questions.text: From the story we know that <blank>.

choices.A: the writer was poor and didn't buy the bookshelf for his wife
choices.B: the writer's wife didn't like the bookshelf
choices.C: the writer was always glad to buy the bookshelf for his wife
choices.D: the writer was not very glad to buy the bookshelf for his wife

questions.explanation: What could I do? Ten minutes later I was twenty dollars poorer.

choices.B: Other drivers would let him go first.
choices.C: His wife could use a new bookshelf.
choices.D: He could save a lot of money and time.

questions.explanation: Other drivers seemed more polite than usual that evening. The police even stopped traffic to let us go through.

choices.B: Because they didn't think it was polite to overtake a car with a bookshelf on it.
choices.C: Because they thought somebody in the writer's family had died and he needed help.
choices.D: Because they thought it was dangerous to carry a bookshelf on a car.

questions.explanation: The police thought it was…er, something else, which means they thought somebody in the writer's family had died.

choices.B: Because at last her husband understood why the police had driven to the church.
choices.C: Because the officer was always looking at the flowers and the bookshelf.
choices.D: Because the police had helped them a lot.

questions.explanation: Suddenly I understood why the police drove here.

question_sets.context:
We've talked about snails(蜗牛) and their slow move. But much of the time snails don't move at all. They're in their shells(壳)――sleeping.
Hot sun will dry out a snail's body. So at the least sign of hot sun, a snail_draws_its body into its shell and closes the opening with a thin cover. Then it goes to sleep. A snail will die in a heavy rain. So whenever it rains, it goes inside its shell house―and goes to sleep. A snail can sleep for as long as it needs to. It can take a short sleep. Or it can sleep for days at a time. And it spends all the winter months in its shell, asleep.
In the spring the snail wakes up. Its body, about three inches(时) long, comes out from the shell. When hungry, the snail looks for food. it can't see very well. its eyes, at the ends of the top feelers(触角), are very weak. But its sense(感觉) of smell is very strong. It helps the snail to the new greens. Then the snail's little mouth goes to work.
A snail's mouth is no bigger than the point of a pin(大头针). Yet it has 25,6000 teeth! The teeth are so small that you can't see them. But they do their work. If you put a snail in a hard paper box, it will eat its way out! And if a snail wears out its teeth, it will grow new ones.
Mostly, a snail looks for food at night. But on cloudy days it eats in the daytime. It eats all day long. A snail can go on eating for hours and never feel full.

questions.text: A snail <blank>.
questions.explanation: But much of the time snails don't move at all. They're in their shells(壳)――sleeping.

questions.explanation: Draw here means pull.

choices.D: the snail's nose is quite short

choices.D: The snail's strong sense of smell helps to find food "far away".

questions.explanation: And if a snail wears out its teeth, it will grow new ones.

question_sets.context:
A woman was collecting money for a church charity. The money she collected was going to be given to poor children who had no parents to take care o them.
She went from house to house. She knocked on doors and s
asked for money. She always said the same thing. ＾Good morning, I'm collecting for a church charity. Please give generously. We need $5,000.￣ Then she held out a collecting box. Most people put a few coins in the box.
An artist lived in one of the apartments. He opened the door to her. ＾Good morning, I'm collecting for a church charity. Please give generously. We need $5,000.￣ The artist thought for a moment, then he said, ＾I'm sorry, but I don't have any money. However, I'll give you a painting. It's worth $400.￣ The woman thanked him and the painting away.
A week later she called on him again. ＾ I'm sorry to trouble you again,￣ she said, ＾but we still need more money. I need another $100. Can you help me?￣ ＾Of course,￣ the artist said. ＾I'll increase the value of my painting to $500.￣

choices.C: He gave her a more valuable painting.
choices.D: He told her to add $100 to the value of the painting.

questions.explanation: He said he would increase the value of the painting to $500.

One of the teachers at my school in Japan told me that your school has summer courses. I am planning to go to the United States next summer and would like to take a short one-month course.
I am 18 years old and have been studying English for six years. I am going to study English at the university. I have ever been to a few countries, such as China, England, Korea, but never to the U.S, and I think a trip will help me improve my English.
Could you send me a catalogue (目录) and application from (申请表)?I would also like information about New Hampshire and other places nearby.
I hope to do some traveling when the course is over.
Thank you in advance (提前) . I look forward to you reply.
Very truly yours,
Mariko Kobori

question_sets.context:
Sam and Joe were astronauts(宇航员). There was once a very dangerous trip and the more experienced(经验) astronauts knew there was only a small chance of coming back. Sam and Joe, however, thought it would be exciting though a little dangerous. "We're the best men for the job," they said to the boss. "There may be problems, but we can find the answers." "They are the last people I'd trust(信任)," thought the boss. "But all the other astronauts have refused(拒绝) to go."
Once they were in space, Joe had to go outside to make some repairs. When the repairs were done, he tried to get back inside the spaceship. But the door was locked. He knocked but there was no answer. He knocked again, louder this time, and again no answer came. Then he hit the door as hard as he could and finally a voice said, "Who's there?" "It's me! Who else could it be?" shouted Joe. Sam let him in. But you can imagine that Joe never asked to go on a trip with Sam again.

question_sets.context:
The Bermuda Triangle(百慕大三角) is in the Atlantic Ocean, near Florida in the USA. During the past 60 years more than 1,000 seamen in the ships and pilots in the planes have lost their lives. It is known as "The Triangle of Heath" for its strange sea water which looks so bright that it can be seen even from the outer spaceship.
At 2:00 p.m. on December 5, 1945, five planes took off in fine weather from the airport of Florida, on a training task. Two hours later, the leader in the sky_radioed_that he was "completely lost". Then there was silence. Another plane was sent to look for them and it disappeared, too.
One of the largest ships that had disappeared in the Triangle was an American coal ship, 500 metres long. The weather was good, and there no messages for help before it was "gone". No broken ships or dead bodies have been found so far.
No one is able to tell how all these accidents have happened. A group of Japanese scientists went there to see what was really like in 1995, but nothing has been heard of ever since then.

There was a boss(老板) in a factory. The boss liked to watch the workers . He wanted the workers to work hard.
One morning the boss came to the factory at nine thirty . A man was drinking coffee. The boss came back at ten fifteen . The man was still drinking coffee. The boss was angry . "How much money do you make a day?" he asked the man.
"One thousand dollars," the man said.
The boss gave the man one thousand dollars. "Take the money and get out of here." He said.
Then the boss asked another worker . "What was the man's job?"
"He doesn't work here," the worker said. " He came to pick up a package(包裹)."

In most parts of the world , many students help their schools make less pollution(污染). They join "environment clubs". In an environment club, people work together to make our environment clean.
Here are some things students often do.
No-garbage(垃圾) lunches. How much do you throw away after lunch? Environment clubs ask students to bring their lunches in bags that can be used
No-car day. On a no-car day, nobody comes to school in a car –not the students and not the teachers ! Cars give pollution to our air, so remember:
Walk , jump , bike or run.
Use your legs! It's lots of fun!
Turn off the water! Did you know that some toilets can waste twenty to forty squares (平方米) of water an hour? In a year , that would fill a small river! In environment clubs , students mend those broken toilets . We love our environment . Let's work together to make it clean.

question_sets.context:
Life in the twenty-first century will be very different from life today. Between then and now many changes will take place, but what will the changes be?
The population is growing fast. There will be many people in the world and most of them will live longer than people live now.
Computers will be much smaller and more useful, and there will be at least one in every home. And computer studies will be one of the important subjects in schools then.
People will work fewer hours than they do now and they will have more free time for sports, watching TV and travelling. Travelling will be much easier and cheaper. And many more people will go to other countries for holidays.
There will be changes in our food, too. Maybe no one will eat meat every day, instead they eat more fruit and vegetables. Maybe people will be healthier.
Work in the future will be different, too. Dangerous and hard work can be done by robots. Because of this, many people will not have enough work to do. This will be a problem.

question_sets.context:
When Ben Franklin was only a boy, he always wanted to know about things. He was always asking his father and brothers "What", "How", "Why".
They couldn't always tell him what he wanted to know.
When they couldn't tell him, Ben tried to find out for himself.
Many times Ben found out things that no one knew before. The other boys would say, "That Ben Franklin! He is always finding out something new!"
Ben lived close to the water. He liked to go there to see the boats. He saw how the wind blew them across the water.
One day Ben said to himself, "Why can't the wind help me float(漂浮) across the water? I'm going to try." Ben jumped into the water.
The wind blew the kite high into the air. Ben began to float across the water. Soon he was on the other side, and he had not worked at all.
One boy shouted, "Look at Ben floating across the water! His kite takes him to the other side without any work!"
"Yes," said another. "He's always finding new ways to do things."

question_sets.context:
Mr and Mrs King have lived in our town for nearly twenty years. They have a book shop by the bus station. They're polite to everyone and have a lot of friends. They often help the poor students and sell them some books cheaply. So there are many young men in their shop. Of course people like them and their friends often call on them and talk with them. We can always hear their rooms are full of laughter and quarrel.
It was a Friday evening. Mr and Mrs King were going to have a picnic on the island the next morning. It was a little far from our town. So they had to get up earlier than usual to catch a six o'clock train. After supper a few friends came to see them while they were cooking some food for the picnic. Mr King and his wife had to stop to receive them. They talked a lot and few of them looked at the clock on the wall. Mr and Mrs King were anxious(焦急的) but they couldn't tell the visitors about it. The woman thought for a few minutes and had an idea. She said to her husband, "Oh, it's eleven o'clock! You'd better stop talking, dear! Our guests must be anxious to go home!"

question_sets.context:
Jess really felt very happy. When he arrived at his seat in the classroom that morning, he found an invitation on his desk. It was from several of his classmates asking him to join them on a camping trip. This was the first time he was asked to join in a out-of-school activity. Why were they asking him now? Nobody seemed to like him. In fact, he had been so lonely that he drowned his feeling with food. As a result, he had put on a lot of weight and this gave the kids something more to make fun of him.
Cindy, who was standing near Jess when he read the invitation, went out quickly to tell the others that the trick had worked. Everyone was pleased that Jess thought that was true. But there was no camping trip. The whole thing was made up.
At first, Cindy thought it was fun.. But later, when Jess told her that he was going to buy a sleeping bag with his savings. Cindy had second thoughts. She knew that Jess's family had little money, and she hated to see him spend his savings on something he would never use. Cindy also hated to tell Jess the truth. Her close friends would be angry with her.
What would she do now"?

question_sets.context:
Life in the twenty-first century will be very different from life today.Between then and now many changes will take place,but what will the changes be?
The population is growing fast.There will be many people in the world and most of them will live longer than people live now.
Computers will be much smaller and more useful,and there will be at least one in every home.And computer studies will be one of the important subjects in schools then.
People will work fewer hours than they do now and they will have more free time for sports,watching TV and travelling.Travelling will be much easier and cheaper.And many more people will go to other countries for holidays.
There will be changes in our food,too.Maybe no one will eat meat every day,instead they eat more fruit and vegetables.Maybe people will be healthier.
Work in the future will be different,too.Dangerous and hard work can be done by robots.Because of this,many people will not have enough work to do.This will be a problem.
